description: Tom Brady will try to prevent the Buffalo Bills from securing a season sweep over the New England Patriots. Later Sunday, Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers and the Atlanta Falcons Matt Ryan will face off in what could be an epic shootout. But those veterans are merely a warm-up for the prime-time clash of two exciting rookie quarterbacks in a game with N.F.C. East implications:

title: Five Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now
description: The architect and designer Emilio Terry could have been a household name  he counted socialites and royalty among his clients, and Salvador Dal and Jean-Michel Frank among his friends  if he hadnt resisted publicity, preferring to fly under the radar. A new exhibition, In Search of Emilio Terry, fills in some of the blanks, combining his own work with pieces from his collection created by his influences and collaborators. The show is helped along with a big assist by Ts beloved contributing editor Konstantin Kakanias, who created a series of new paintings starring Mrs. Tependris, the fictional society doyenne he has been drawing for the last 20 years. On view through Nov. 12 at Eerdmans Fine Art, 14 E. 10th St., eerdmansfineart.com.  ALEXANDRIA SYMONDS

title: Regional Japanese Fare Comes to America
description: In the States, weve tended to think of Japanese food as a single cuisine that includes raw fish, teriyaki, tempura and ramen. In Japan, as elsewhere, there are hyperlocal specialties: fried chicken in Nagoya, grilled oysters from Miyajima, tangerines and green tea in Shizuoka. Now, a crop of new restaurants is finally introducing some of this regional nuance to American diners. Ichiran, which opened last month in Brooklyn, has only one thing on the menu: tonkotsu ramen served Fukuoka-style, with straight, thin noodles and a rich pork-bone broth. TsuruTonTan in Manhattan specializes in udon from the Kansai region, served hot in a fish-based dashi or twisted over a bed of ice with a soy dipping sauce. Over in L.A., Shibumi offers kappo, a tradition in which the chef presents seasonal small plates  like Nagano-inspired fresh soba noodles in November  to diners at the counter.

title: Keeping Your Affordable Care Act Plan Affordable
description: INSURER defections and double-digit premium increases may be making consumers wary of seeking health insurance through Affordable Care Act marketplaces. But despite the turmoil, health care advocates are still urging people to shop for 2017 coverage when the annual open enrollment period begins on Tuesday.

title: Review: The Pumpkin Pie Show, Night of the Voting Dead
description: There is no shortage of comedians weighing in on the current election, but it often seems like the tools of satire are insufficient to comment on this absurd and exhausting campaign. Perhaps we need to look to a darker corner of the culture, where the punch lines end with bruises.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Tracey Ullmans Show, Friday, 11 p.m., HBO

title: Blasting Out of a Trump Trap
description: For anyone who predicted at the infancy of Donald J. Trumps presidential bid  so many mean, vengeful, condemning, deranged remarks ago  that the unhinged nature his candidacy revealed would surely serve his business interests poorly, the past few weeks have delivered gratifying confirmation. Residents of a row of Trump buildings on Riverside Boulevard on the Upper West Side are rallying to have the Republican nominees name expunged from the facades. Simultaneously, protests have mounted against the United States Golf Associations plan to hold the United States Womens Open next year  at a Trump course in New Jersey, where it was scheduled four years ago, on the theory that holding it there would be like celebrating Earth Day in a pesticide factory.

title: Tension Between Police and Standing Rock Protesters Reaches Boiling Point
description: CANNON BALL, N.D.  For months, tensions had mounted between protesters and law enforcement officials over the fate of an oil pipeline not far from the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation. Late this week, the strained relations boiled over as officers tried to force the protesters out of an area where they had been camping.

title: Images of a Less Crowded New York
description: If you ask me my favorite place, it was probably Times Square, said the photographer Philip Trager, whose book New York in the 1970s was published last week.

title: Images of 1970s New York
description: Philip Trager, now 81, found a box of his old negatives of the city from a decade known as raucous. The photographs appear in a newly published book.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Thrillers and True Crime
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: Were hiring three journalists to help shape opinion coverage at The New York Times
description: In an editor role we're looking for a person who defines editing broadly, from written columns to interactive stories and reader engagement. We also seek two visual journalists to join the team.

title: Wall St. Poised for Higher Profits but Fewer Jobs, Report Says
description: Wall Street is on track to reverse three consecutive years of profit declines, but bonuses and jobs continue to shrink as the industry adjusts to a postcrisis world, a new report shows.

title: Coastal Jointweed Brings Fall Blooms to Citys Barrens
description: It is interesting how the driest, most barren landscapes are often graced by plants as elegant as coastal jointweed.

title: Chinese Vessels Leave Disputed Fishing Grounds in South China Sea
description: MANILA  Chinese vessels have quietly abandoned the contested Scarborough Shoal, the Philippine government said Friday, apparently a concession by Beijing after a visit to China by President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines.

title: Soylent Says It Will Remake Two of Its Meal Replacers After Customers Became Ill
description: Soylent, the company that made beige meal replacement products a Silicon Valley favorite, said on Thursday that it would reformulate its line of protein bars and a powder mix, the latest in a string of updates the company has issued after customers reported gastrointestinal issues.

title: Review: To Pixar and Beyond Plumbs New Depth in Oft-Told Tale
description: The most successful animated films have made their fortune not just from endless repeat viewing by children, but from simultaneously engaging an adult audience.

title: In Line for Blessings and Sweets at Hindu Temple Canteen
description: On a recent Saturday afternoon at a Hindu temple in Queens, a crowd assembled there was spilling out onto Holly Avenue. It was two weeks before Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, and the din from inside sounded more like a busy train station than a serene temple.

title: Why Israel Still Refuses to Choose
description: TEL AVIV  There is agreement on very little in the fractious Holy Land, but on one issue there is near unanimity these days: A two-state resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is more distant than ever, so unimaginable that it appears little more than an illusion sustained by lazy thinking, interest in the status quo or plain exhaustion.

title: What New York Hoaxes Have Rivaled the One on the Scary Clowns?
description: Q. I worry more about the creepy clowns in the news lately than about the ghouls, goblins and mini-Trumps and mini-Clintons who will soon be knocking at my door. Now Im told its all a big hoax. Have any New York hoaxes rivaled that of the clowns?

title: Immigrant New Yorks Birth Over 4 Centuries
description: Within a few decades of founding New Amsterdam, the Dutch built a wall, first to keep out the Indians, then the British. But because the Dutch came to the New World to make money  rather than to proselytize or escape religious persecution  they let in just about everybody else.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties are six-bedroom homes in East Hills, N.Y., and Saddle River, N.J.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: Whats Your Commute Time Worth?
description: Whats a minute spent commuting worth to home buyers?

title: Emails in Anthony Weiner Inquiry Jolt Hillary Clintons Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  The presidential campaign was rocked on Friday after federal law enforcement officials said that emails pertinent to the closed investigation into Hillary Clintons private email server were discovered on a computer belonging to Anthony D. Weiner, the estranged husband of a top Clinton aide.

title: Accusations of Quid Pro Quo at the Clinton Foundation
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Lopez Will Star in a Live TV Adaptation of Bye Bye Birdie
description: NBCs next live musical event will be the 1960 Broadway show Bye Bye Birdie, the network announced on Thursday, with Jennifer Lopez starring in the role of Rosie.

title: A Scaredy-Cats Investigation Into Why People Enjoy Fear
description: Halloween is here again. That means your co-workers have planted surprise spiders around the office. Youve been invited to a haunted hayride. Your neighbors yard has a full cemetery, rigged with motion detectors and pop-up zombies. Chicken-livered from the start, I have always dreaded this time of year. Haunted houses, ghost tours and horror film fests are not my thing, and why people love having the daylights scared out of them completely escapes me.

title: Borrow E-Books, No Kindle Required
description: Q. Do you have to have a Kindle to borrow e-books from the library? Can you use a different device or computer instead?

title: My Six-Hour Interview with Warren Beatty
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, the reporter Cara Buckley describes the reporting she did for a profile on the actor Warren Beatty.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are on the Upper West Side, in Greenwich Village, and in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: A Dancer Brings His Rocky Mountain Laboratory to New York
description: For the past several summers, dance collaborations have blossomed on a stage nestled in the Rocky Mountains. The Vail International Dance Festival, led by Damian Woetzel, brings together dancers, choreographers and musicians for a most worthwhile purpose: artistic discovery.

title: The Worst Tax Dodgers
description: To the Editor:

title: Daily Report: When Your Company is Famous but Unprofitable
description: Imagine you run Twitter, a social network that has played an important role in the most volatile presidential election in decades  maybe ever. The candidates post their opinions there, sometimes in the middle of the night. Reporters go there. Voters go there. And what is said there is often more important than what is said at campaign rallies.

title: An Airy Store in a New Delhi Palace
description: New Delhi  Mute testament to the vanity of greatness, the once-resplendent city bungalow of the maharajahs of Bikaner stood forlorn for decades, a sad old heap at the center of this city.

title: Justice Obama?
description: To the Editor:

title: Minimalist Composer Julius Eastman, Dead for 26 Years, Crashes the Canon
description: When Julius Eastman died in 1990, almost no one knew. It wasnt until an obituary appeared in The Village Voice eight months later that his friends and colleagues got the news.

title: A Retirement Made for Walking?
description: To the Editor:

title: Go to Borussia Dortmund, Young Man. And Maybe Even Stay.
description: DORTMUND, Germany  The choice in front of Ousmane Dembl, a teenage French forward of almost limitless promise, was flattering and bewildering in equal measure. He had just turned 19, and he had only one season of senior-level soccer  with Rennes, a modest team in Frances top division  under his belt. Yet by last summer, he had become one of the most coveted players on the planet.

title: New Condos and Rentals on East Houston Street
description: For decades, East Houston Street was more a place to cross  and quickly, to avoid speeding cars  than a destination. Residential developers, too, seemed to shun it, wary of its commercial character and odd-shaped scraps of lots.

title: Facebook Can Tell You What to Expect in the Voting Booth
description: Facebook is using its enormous reach to get out the informed vote on Election Day.

title: Exxon Concedes It May Need to Declare Lower Value for Oil in Ground
description: HOUSTON  Exxon Mobil, in a concession to market and regulatory pressures, said Friday that it might be forced to write down the value of some of its oil and gas assets in Canada and elsewhere if energy prices remain low through the end of the year.

title: In Lucky Penny, a Life in Bits and Pieces
description: Its hard to pinpoint when exactly David Deblingers Lucky Penny was born, since he has been collecting the stories in his one-man show over many years, like loose change found on the sidewalk.

title: Jrme Bel: Naked and Alive, Then Clothed and Dead
description: Many years ago, Jrme Bel had some genuinely provocative ideas. In the second and final week that the Crossing The Line festival has been focusing on this French choreographer, those ideas were the revelation in the New York premiere of his early work Jrme Bel, even as the premiere of his new, festival-commissioned MoMA Dance Company exhibited how his recent art has shrunken into lazy formulas.

title: Visiting Cold Spring, Where the Path to Ruins Goes Uphill
description: A wooded footpath winding up to the mysterious ruins of a mansion is one of the more striking marvels of Cold Spring, N.Y., a Putnam County village just over an hour north of Grand Central Terminal by rail. From the station, its a short walk to Main Street, a picture postcard of 19th- and early 20th-century commercial facades with an alluring mix of antique shops, art galleries and restaurants.

title: Baker Hughes Could Be a Good Fit for General Electric
description: General Electric says it is not planning to acquire the $23 billion oil-services company Baker Hughes, contrary to news reports. But shareholders should not be shocked by the idea that G.E. might take a look.

title: Thats a Lot of Rabbits
description: The rabbit lady of Gowanus opened the gate onto a lunar landscape of gray dirt and holes. Rabbits of every possible size and color hopped and groomed and basked in the sun.

title: Long Before Twitter, Martin Luther Was a Media Pioneer
description: Americans may know the basics of how Martin Luther was said to have nailed his 95 theses to a church door in Wittenberg, Germany, in 1517, condemning the Roman Catholic Churchs sale of indulgences, but they probably dont realize how Luther strategically used the media of his time: books, paintings, prints and music.

title: How Dylan Thuras, a Founder of Atlas Obscura, Spends His Sundays
description: For someone who catalogs strange and unexplored corners of the globe, Dylan Thuras, a founder of Atlas Obscura and an author of Atlas Obscura: An Explorers Guide to the Worlds Hidden Wonders, keeps it pretty local. Mr. Thuras, 34, lives in the Greenpoint neighborhood of Brooklyn with his wife, Michelle J. Enemark, 34, an animator, and their 22-month-old son, Phineas. The Atlas Obscura office is in the Pencil Factory, and Mr. Thurass apartment is just three blocks away, in a building that used to house employees of Astral Oil Works. One of their slogans, he said, was Will not explode!

title: Opioid Addiction Study
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
description: Its a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And theres much more where these came from.

title: A Cure for Liberal Worries
description: To the Editor:

title: Unrest in Kashmir Claims New Casualties: Schools
description: HABBER, Kashmir  It happened again on Thursday night: Another village school was burned to the ground.

title: Pork Stew Gets a Chile Kick
description: Beef stews are homey. Lamb stews are fancy. But only rarely do I consider the pork stew.

title: ISIS Using Human Shields in Mosul, U.N. Reports
description: Islamic State fighters are using tens of thousands of people as human shields while government and Kurdish forces battle to reclaim Mosul, United Nations human rights investigators reported on Friday.

title: New York Theater Artists Latest Muse: Donald Trump
description: The volunteers worked busily in a campaign office for Donald J. Trump in Manhattan decorated with Trump posters and other campaign materials. One worker was reading Mr. Trumps book The Art of the Deal.

title: Russia Loses Seat on U.N. Human Rights Council
description: UNITED NATIONS  Russia narrowly lost its seat on the main United Nations body devoted to human rights on Friday, signaling international dismay over the military powers conduct in Syria.

title: Review: The Fall Returns, but Will the Deadly Hunt Continue?
description: The Fall, Allan Cubitts somber, slow-brewing serial-killer drama for Irish and British television  and Netflix, where its third season goes up on Saturday  leads a kind of double existence. Its a crime drama thats also a treatise on violence against women and the sources of male rage, and there are frequently times when it works better as case study than as storytelling.

title: Every Family Has a Witching Hour
description: Every parent knows that at certain times of day  the time between naps or after dinner  life gets a little more challenging.

title: Letter to Congress From F.B.I. Director on Clinton Email Case
description: In the letter, the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said that new emails had surfaced in a case unrelated to the closed investigation into whether Hillary Clinton or her aides had mishandled classified information, and that the messages appear to be pertinent to the investigation.

title: Putin Ally Died in U.S. After Drunken Fall, Not Foul Play, Prosecutors Say
description: WASHINGTON  The mysterious death here of a prominent Russian businessman and former government minister last year was an accident caused by a drunken fall inside his hotel room, the prosecutors office announced on Friday as investigators officially closed the case.

title: What Was Your First Brush With a Gender Barrier?
description: The New York Times would like to hear from women about their experience with a gender barrier.

title: The Playlist: Shakira Takes Charge and Protest Rap Is Still Alive
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter (coming soon!) here.

title: Why Halloween at College Is So Frightening
description: ATLANTA  Were coming up on Halloween, the most frightening time of the year  for college administrators. The debate over what costumes are too offensive to be worn on campus prompts some outsize emotions. Yale last year lost valuable faculty members because of a letter one of them wrote questioning prohibitions on Halloween costumes. The ensuing dispute was a national embarrassment, and it set Yale back $50 million in new diversity initiatives.

title: With Headgear Here, Girls Lacrosse Just Got Safer. Or Did It?
description: Addressing growing concerns about head injuries, two companies this month became the first to sell lacrosse headgear that is built specifically for girls and that complies with new standards from the sports governing body. But the availability of the equipment has only made the touchy debate over whether girls should wear it even more stark.

title: Talk of Violence if Donald Trump Is Defeated
description: To the Editor:

title: Camille Becerra Finds a Home via Instagram
description: In 17 years of renting in New York, Camille Becerra found all her apartments through friends or word of mouth. But last November, when the man from whom she was renting an apartment in Chinatown gave her just 30 days to leave, she turned to a much larger social network: the photo-sharing site Instagram.

title: Reviewing Toaster Ovens, and Selling Them, Too
description: The New York Times grabbed a few modest headlines earlier this week when it purchased a popular website called The Wirecutter that recommends a variety of consumer products to its customers. The Times paid an estimated $30 million, a relatively small sum for a media giant that takes in that much revenue every seven days.

title: Diverse Looks in the Indian Capital
description: Bright colors and dark, wild-patterned and plain, traditional and modern: the men of New Delhi and environs have a sharp, distinctive style.

title: Distinctly New Delhi
description: Its easy to find stylish men in New Delhi and its environs. Whether dressed in wild-patterned clothes or plain, traditional or modern, men from all walks of life in this city  as diverse as fashion designers and carnival workers  have achieved a distinctive blend of ease and fashion sense.

title: Technology Invites a Deep Dive Into Art
description: For many years, patrons were asked to turn off their cellphones when they entered a museum. Now, theyre encouraged to use them with technologies like augmented and virtual reality, touch-screen tables and customized audio tours. The goal is to enhance the visitors experience while keeping the artwork front and center. Here are some examples.

title: Canada Today: New Challenges for Syrian Refugees
description: The struggles and dangers that refugees from Syria endure before reaching safe havens are now well known. For the second part of their insightful and often moving long-term look at Syrian refugees in Canada, Jodi Kantor and Catrin Einhorn were in Toronto, where they found an additional stress factor that newcomers faced after they arrived at their new homes.

title: Mary Halvorson on Guitar: Unflinching and Full of Grace
description: Theres no other sound in music precisely like Mary Halvorsons guitar, which she plays with a flinty attack, a spidery finesse and a shiver of wobbly delay. At National Sawdust in Brooklyn last Saturday, that sound was an unmistakable force during a prime-time stretch of John Zorns bagatelles marathon, which featured 20 groupings of musicians over a 10-hour concert sprawl.

title: Review: The Philharmonics Concertmaster Steps Into the Spotlight
description: The New York Philharmonics selection of Frank Huang as its concertmaster last year was a critical decision in Alan Gilberts tenure as music director. Ive made a lot of appointments, Mr. Gilbert said at the time, but this is obviously the most crucial.

title: Millers Wipeout Slider
description: Andrew Miller, the versatile and dominant reliever for the Indians, throws a slider that gives hitters fits. Heres what makes it so tough to hit.

title: Supreme Court to Rule in Transgender Access Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday entered the national debate over transgender rights, announcing that it would decide whether a transgender boy may use the boys bathroom in a Virginia high school.

title: Drugs Were Around Me Every Day
description: Cassidy McDonald is the 2016 win-a-trip winner. This month she traveled with Nicholas Kristof through Arkansas and Oklahoma to report on domestic poverty.

title: Ballet and Folk Art Nights
description: Last weeks fall galas and parties included the American Ballet Theatre, Tefaf opening, Studio Museum in Harlem, Aperture Foundation and the American Folk Art Museum.

title: Ballet and Folk Art Nights
description: Like the colors of fall, the charity season neared its peak last week, with five or more galas vying for support on a single night. The American Ballet Theater held its fall gala on Oct. 20, with a premiere of Benjamin Millepieds Daphnis and Chloe at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center. Tefaf New York, the American debut of the European art fair, held an opening-night preview at the Park Avenue Armory on Oct. 21, benefiting the Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering.

title: Soccer Without Headers? New Research Shows Its Worth Discussing
description: WEST NEWBURY, Mass.  Soccer without headers? My team has experienced it for the last two months, and we may not be ahead of the curve for long.

title: In Rare New Jersey Swing District, House Race Becomes a Brawl
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J.  With a barrage of negative ads and copious outside spending, the congressional race in a crescent of Norman Rockwell-style suburbs and tidy rural villages in northern New Jersey represents one of the regions most bare-knuckle political fights.

title: How Pepe the Frog and Nasty Woman Are Shaping the Election
description: Pepe the Frog, Nasty Woman, #NeverTrump.

title: Why Dakota Is the New Keystone
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt.  The Native Americans who have spent the last months in peaceful protest against an oil pipeline along the banks of the Missouri are standing up for tribal rights. Theyre also standing up for clean water, environmental justice and a working climate. And its time that everyone else joined in.

title: Licensed to Eat Fire (Valid One Year Only)
description: If you wanted to run away with the circus, it would be as easy right now as it has ever been. But you would have to provide a lot of paperwork: photo ID, proof of professional insurance and an E29 fire performers license from the New York Fire Department.

title: Review: What Would Sophocles Do? Pucker Up, Perhaps
description: A tickling breeze of possibilities ripples through Two Class Acts, short plays of modern love and ancient days in repertory at the Flea Theater. That spirit, with its enthusiastic sense of arts potential to portray and effect transformations, is youthful in nature. And it feels appropriate that the performers in these productions would all seem to be on the sunny side of 30.

title: Gerard Alessandrini: Man of Many Broadway Spoofs
description: It was a four-hour commute from Needham, Mass., Gerard Alessandrinis longtime home, to Manhattan, his frequent place of business. The trip was becoming burdensome for Mr. Alessandrini, 62, a one-time actor and singer who struck a chord  and gold  with his musical-theater spoof Forbidden Broadway.

title: What I Love | Gerard Alessandrini
description: Gerard Alessandrini, the creator of the Spamilton, and his partner, Glenn Bassett, share a weekend getaway in Eastern Connecticut.

title: The F.B.I. and the Clinton Emails
description: To the Editor:

title: Review: A Group of Young Dancers, Conversing With their Feet
description: The seven New York City Ballet dancers who performed in BalletCollectives What Comes Next program looked fresh, unaffected, contemporary. They (five women, two men) walked onto the stage on their heels, their manner casual. After a step or a sequence, they let their arms swing and stood on flat feet. They were not improvising, but the mood was spontaneous.

title: Museums, the New Social Media Darlings
description: Talk about a mash-up. Perhaps the most ephemeral of social media channels, Snapchat, is being used to pair pop lyrics with images of centuries-old paintings or artifacts. The images last on a device for up to 10 seconds.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Review: A Low-Key Debut for the New Jersey Symphonys Director
description: NEWARK  Xian Zhangs debut as music director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra on Thursday afternoon was in some ways oddly understated.

title: Barnes Foundations Director Aims to Unpack the Ideas in the Art
description: PHILADELPHIA  The ghost of Dr. Albert C. Barnes, the visionary collector and undisputed eccentric who once replied Nuts to T. S. Eliots request for a visit to his renowned holdings, still hovers here at the Barnes Foundation, even in the new building by the architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, which opened in 2012.

title: Dispute at Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812 Leads to a Lawsuit
description: The nonprofit theater that commissioned Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812 says it has filed suit against the shows commercial producer after unsuccessful attempts to settle an  ugly dispute that is casting a shadow over one of the Broadway seasons most promising musicals.

title: 5 Vine Stars Share Why They Loved, and Outgrew, Platform
description: When Vine announced on Thursday that it would close down in the coming months, thousands of the video platforms greatest hits were shared across the internet in six-second bursts.

title: Art and Politics Meet in Boston, Sometimes All Night
description: BOSTON  This fall, Political Intent, a new exhibition at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, is conducting an experiment on how to talk politics with gallery visitors. The show, by eight female artists from four continents, is part of #mfaNOW, an initiative aimed at dissolving the starchy separations between museum and community, politics and art, contemporary work and older pieces. The goal is to push visitors experience beyond the rarefied gallery walls and encourage discourse on complex topics inside the museum and in the surrounding world.

title: Craving a Hot TV Show in China? Start Scouring the Web
description: BEIJING  The Journey of Flower is a novel that has never been sold in bookstores. It was first published on a literature website in 2009, but its story, a martial arts fantasy, is now one of Chinas most successful brands.

title: Icons of Modern Art: Picassos, Matisses, Monets, Oh, My!
description: PARIS  The history of collecting, the development of painterly style, the changing fortunes of individuals and nations: You will think about all these things on your second go-through of Icons of Modern Art: The Shchukin Collection, which opened last week at the Fondation Louis Vuitton here.

title: Review: In the Room, About Lessons Learned at a Writing Workshop
description: All six of them are instantly hateable. The way they enter, slam their books and things on the table and angrily take their seats, in unison. Then Rainer (Suzy Jane Hunt) arrives, inconsiderately late, and she turns out to be married to a movie star.

title: First Baby in Puerto Rico With Zika-Related Microcephaly Born
description: The first child in Puerto Rico with Zika-related microcephaly has been born, the territorys secretary of health announced Friday.

title: Clinton, Trump, Halloween: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Founder Says Rolling Stone Erred in Retracting Rape Article
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  In a defiant defense of the magazine he founded and owns, Jann S. Wenner said Rolling Stone was wrong to fully retract a discredited 2014 article about allegations of a gang rape at the University of Virginia, asserting in videotaped testimony shown on Friday that much of the material in the article was correct.

title: The Kind of Thinking Cities Need
description: Quito, Ecuador  Day after day, under a bright sun, hourslong security lines snaked out of El Ejido Park into the surrounding streets. Enterprising women in multicolored skirts and brown hats sold water and folding umbrellas for shade. Inside, representatives at the German pavilion seduced passers-by with beer and apples to spread propaganda on the circular economy, while the incongruous sound of a mariachi band playing Frank Sinatra music wafted from Ecuadors booth, nearly drowning out a speech by an architect from California describing her companys projects to improve a slum in Kenya.

title: John Zacherle, Host With a Ghoulish Perspective, Dies at 98
description: John Zacherle, one of the first of the late-night television horror-movie hosts, who played a crypt-dwelling undertaker with a booming graveyard laugh on stations in Philadelphia and New York in the late 1950s and early 60s, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

title: How Dairy Farmers in Belgium Held Up a Big E.U. Trade Deal
description: SIPPENAEKEN, Belgium  Christian Wiertz worked his usual 14 hours on Thursday, milking 85 cows at his family farm in this village in eastern Belgium, near the border with the Netherlands.

title: Franois Hollande, His Ratings Poor, Speaks Candidly. The Hole Gets Deeper.
description: PARIS  The living dead have long haunted French politics. Some resurrect themselves after near-death experiences in politics, while others continue to appear politically alive even when they have actually died.

title: Medicaid Finds Opportune Time to Offer Birth Control: Right After Birth
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Last month, Akia Gayle gave birth to her third child. Sixteen hours later, while she was still in her hospital bed, a doctor implanted a matchstick-size plastic rod in her left arm because she did not want to have a fourth.

title: Key Moments in the Downfall of Anthony Weiner
description: The revelation that the federal authorities had found a trove of emails related to their investigation into Hillary Clintons private email server appear to be the latest fallout from an unlikely source: Anthony D. Weiner, a Democrat who once represented New York in Congress and also ran for mayor.

title: Venezuela Slowed by Strike in Campaign to Oust President Nicols Maduro
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Much of Caracas and other cities slowed to a Sunday crawl on Friday as many Venezuelans heeded the oppositions call for a general strike, a step in its campaign to force a referendum to remove President Nicols Maduro.

title: Bob Dylan Speaks, at Last, on His Nobel
description: We finally have an answer. Bob Dylan will, indeed, accept his Nobel Prize in Literature  probably.

title: Plane Preparing to Take Off at OHare Catches Fire
description: CHICAGO  About 20 people were taken to hospitals with minor injuries Friday after an American Airlines jet preparing to take off for Miami caught fire on the runway at OHare International Airport, officials said.

title: Flint, and Michigan, Brace for More Charges in Water Inquiry
description: LANSING, Mich.  As Flint continues to suffer from a water crisis, one question percolates here in Michigans capital: Who will be charged next?

title: World Series: Heres How the Indians Won Game 3
description: Chicago Cubs fans waited 71 years for the World Series to return to Wrigley Field. But when it did on Friday night, the result was not what they were looking for.

title: This Changes Everything: Donald Trump Exults as Hillary Clintons Team Scrambles
description: Everything was looking up for Hillary Clinton. She was riding high in the polls, even seeing an improvement on trustworthiness. She was sitting on $153 million in cash. At 12:37 p.m. Friday, her aides announced that she planned to campaign in Arizona, a state that a Democratic presidential candidate has carried only once since 1948.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: It is extraordinary that we would see something like this just 11 days out from a presidential election.

title: Emails Again, This Time With Anthony Weiner
description: Every time Americans start thinking nothing more can surprise them in this presidential campaign, something detonates to prove them wrong. So it was that on Friday, 11 days from Election Day, the F.B.I. director, James Comey, sent a cryptic letter to Congress saying, In connection with an unrelated case, the F.B.I. has learned of the existence of emails that appear pertinent to its investigation of Hillary Clintons private email server.

title: Knicks Need Time to Regroup (or Just to Group)
description: The Knicks were disjointed and scattered on opening night in Cleveland, like a high-profile jam band not yet in tune. The 29-point loss to the Cavaliers on Tuesday provided evidence of their disconnection, in the form of myriad missed shots and impotent defense. It also left them hankering to play again  with nearly four days to digest their disappointment.

title: Campaign to Bring Casino Gambling to North Jersey Appears Doomed
description: For those looking for a good bet on election night results, the smart money in New Jersey says a referendum on whether to expand casino gambling in the state is headed for defeat.

title: Telecoms Ambitions on Targeted Ads Seen Curbed by F.C.C.s New Privacy Rules
description: In recent years, companies like Verizon and AT&T have made no secret of their ambitions to build online advertising businesses that can take on the behemoths of Silicon Valley.

title: Twitters 4-Year Odyssey With the 6-Second Video App Vine
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Twitter bought Vine in 2012, it was a three-man company planning an app of six-second videos that had yet to even launch. Still, Jack Dorsey, Twitters co-founder who had pushed for the deal, thought he had found the next big thing in social media  an Instagram with video.

title: For First Time in 17 Years, Women Will Compete in Top Big-Wave Surfing Contest
description: For the first time in the competitions 17-year history, women will be allowed to compete at Mavericks, the nations premier big-wave surfing contest, held off the northern coast of California.

title: Chicago Cubs Fortunes Have Changed, but Wrigley Field Remains a Site of Pilgrimage
description: CHICAGO  So much has changed since the Chicago Cubs last appeared in the World Series, but their home is the same as it was in 1945: Wrigley Field, at the corner of Clark and Addison, on the North Side of town.

title: In Closing Words at Bridge Trial, Prosecution Returns to a Familiar Email
description: NEWARK  Three years after the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge and at the end of a six-week trial against two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey who are accused of orchestrating them, the prosecution closed its case here on Friday by returning to the stark directive that started the whole thing.

title: F.B.I. Chief James Comey Is in Political Crossfire Again Over Emails
description: WASHINGTON  James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director, faced a dilemma on Thursday when deputies briefed him about the discovery of a trove of emails that might be linked to the inquiry into Hillary Clintons private email server that was closed months ago.

title: New Trend in Baseball: Custom Cleats for the Polished Player
description: Javier Baez, the Chicago Cubs flashy second baseman, loves sneakers so much, and has such an extensive collection, that he had them converted into cleats to use on the baseball diamond. Indians shortstop Francisco Lindor has worn jazzed-up, red-and-blue cleats throughout the playoffs that feature the Cleveland skyline and the word Believeland written in gold across a side.

title: Endorsements in New York and New Jersey
description: This elections most dire priority is averting a national and planetary calamity (two words: President Trump). But Nov. 8 is also about good government at all levels. Here are some congressional and state races in New York  and New Jersey where voters can make a difference.

title: The Ultimate Protest Vote
description: On Nov. 8 I will be going to the polls and voting, without hesitation or disinclination, for Hillary Clinton. But what a treacherous and unforgivable act this will be for my father, who will no doubt be supporting the only presidential candidate he believes has any chance of saving the United States from almost certain ruin: Alyson Kennedy.

title: Bready Bunch
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  A tough one by Patrick Berry today, and the cluing is ramped up to what one would expect in a Saturday crossword. This one was a three-separate-tries puzzle for me, but I finally cracked it.

title: The Pleasure and Pain of the Climbing Life
description: As a runt kid in a college town in Pennsylvania, I dreamed of grand adventures. Hidden treasures, human flight and sports, of course. I was going to be a football star. But in 10th grade, I weighed 85 pounds. The coaches refused to issue me equipment, breaking my heart but surely saving my life. Weight-class sports suited me better. I started boxing. My ethos was: train hard, never quit. It was enough to carry me to a collegiate national boxing title in 1990 (by then at 132 pounds). Then I moved to Montana for graduate school.

title: Arrests and Violence at Pipeline Protest
description: Demonstrators at the Dakota Access pipeline were shot at with beanbag bag rounds, hit with pepper spray and taken into custody by the police.

title: Style, Not Age
description: Not all women listen to the advice to dress your age  i.e., prim and dull.

title: Echo of Jeremy Lins Glory Days as Nets Win Home Opener
description: Jeremy Lins work for the Nets began about five minutes before the tip. He grabbed a microphone and thanked the fans at Barclays Center for coming to the Nets home opener on Friday against the Indiana Pacers. The crowd cheered. The building was brimming with hope.

title: Sophia Cranshaw, MTV Producer of Social-Issue Campaigns, Dies at 45
description: Sophia Cranshaw, an MTV producer, director and writer who was honored for her campaigns against genocide, the stigma of mental illness and other sweeping social crises, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 45.

title: Susan Lindquist, Scientist Who Made Genetic Discoveries Using Yeast, Dies at 67
description: Susan Lindquist, a molecular biologist whose conceptually daring work with yeast proteins opened new avenues to understanding gene functioning and degenerative diseases like Parkinsons and Alzheimers, died on Thursday in Boston. She was 67.

title: Mexicos Formula One Evokes Go-Karts at Slippery Speeds
description: Slippery and like a go-kart track. That might be the best way to describe driving conditions on the newly renovated Autdromo Hermanos Rodrguez track, when the Mexican Grand Prix returned there last year after a 23-year absence.

title: The 1970 Mexican Grand Prix Was One of Passion and Chaos
description: Most people would rather forget Mexico 1970 were the last words of the contemporary race report in Motor Sport magazine, summing up the feeling after that running of the Mexican Grand Prix.

title: A Young Drivers Defensive Tactics Divide Rivals
description: There is no purer moment in auto racing than the instant when a car pulls out from inches behind a competitor and powers past, gaining a position.

title: Why Some Drivers Are Hired, Despite Their Records
description: As Formula One prepares for the Mexican Grand Prix this weekend, only three races remain in the 2016 season and most teams have decided who will drive for them next year.

title: Grand Prix Royalty, Looking to Rebound
description: The Williams Grand Prix team may not have scored a Formula One title since 1997, but it is still the series third most successful outfit and remains one of the famous names at the pinnacle of auto racing.

title: For Race Fans in Mexico, Native Sons on Overlapping Paths
description: Not since the brothers Pedro and Ricardo Rodrguez raced in Formula One in the 1960s have two Mexicans whipped up as much passion for the series as have Sergio Prez and Esteban Gutirrez.

title: Corrections: October 29, 2016
description: NEW YORK

title: Richard Pittman, Marine Who Fended Off Vietnam Ambush, Dies at 71
description: Richard A. Pittman, a Marine who earned the Medal of Honor for charging into a North Vietnamese ambush under heavy fire and fending off dozens of enemy troops in 1966, died on Oct. 13 in Stockton, Calif. He was 71.

title: Miming Photo in End Zone? Negative, the N.F.L. Says
description: The N.F.L. fined Giants defensive end Owa Odighizuwa $12,154 for an unsportsmanlike-conduct penalty issued after he pretended to take a picture in the end zone of safety Landon Collins, who returned an interception for a touchdown against Los Angeles in London last Sunday.

title: Indians Pitchers Roar to Life, and the Cubs Bats Fall Silent
description: CHICAGO  When the Cleveland Indians arrived in town, they were viewed as a prop. The city was buzzing on Friday, bars in Wrigleyville were hopping before lunch and ticket prices for the Chicago Cubs first World Series home game in 71 years were approaching the cost of a college tuition payment.

title: Andrew Miller Is Called Upon for the Fifth Inning. Rollie Fingers Can Relate.
description: CHICAGO  As he watched Game 3 of the World Series on Friday from his home in Las Vegas, Rollie Fingers thought back to some of the moments that defined his Hall of Fame career. At a raucous Wrigley Field, the Cleveland Indians were calling for their best reliever, Andrew Miller, with a runner on second in a scoreless game against the Cubs  in the fifth inning. Fingers could relate.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: The Fall and Pride and Prejudice and Zombies
description: Whos dead? No one but the victims, or so it seems, as The Fall returns. Pride and Prejudice and Zombies bloodies up Jane Austens classic as Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy battle the undead. And 48 Hours examines a case cracked by a butt dial.

title: Police Shoot Armed Man at Queens Housing Complex
description: Police officers patrolling a public housing complex in Queens shot an armed man in the leg on Friday night after he failed to obey their orders to drop his gun, the police said.

title: Trumps Going to Bake an Inauguration Cake Out of This
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

title: For AT&T Chief, Time Warner Deal Is the Peak of an Ambitious Climb
description: Randall L. Stephenson, the chief executive of AT&T, could easily be pigeonholed as just another empire-building executive with a white-bread rsum. He is a 56-year-old Republican from Oklahoma atop a 140-year-old company, whose extracurricular highlights include serving as president of the Boy Scouts of America and shaping professional golf as a policy board member for the PGA Tour.

title: No Kegs, No Liquor: College Crackdown Targets Drinking and Sexual Assault
description: The backyard fraternity party was in full dancing, drinking mode on a recent Saturday morning. To the sounds of No Problem by Chance the Rapper, Breanna DeCocker, 20, a junior at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, Mich., ducked through the crowd holding a clipboard.

title: Judging Others by Their Email Tics
description: Perhaps it was the lack of sleep, but I recently found myself having a full-fledged meltdown, prompted by an email signature. Specifically, my own email signature (or lack of one): that little one-line signoff that comes at the end of your iPhone message, telling the person on the other end that youve sent the message from your mobile device.

title: After Scandal, and With Staff Intact, Baylor Remains a Big 12 Power
description: WACO, Tex.  When Baylor University released a damning summary in May of an investigation into sexual assault accusations and convictions involving football players, the consequences were swift. The universitys president, Kenneth W. Starr, was demoted. The athletic director, Ian McCaw, resigned. The football coach, Art Briles, was effectively fired.

title: Rachel Maddow and Doris Kearns Goodwin on a Presidential Race for the History Books
description: History offers strange consolation: No matter how alarming current events (or a presidential election) may be, historians can usually point to analogous episodes we survived in the past.

title: Fast Times on the Campaign Trail in Embeds
description: This month, a group of 20-somethings assembled in Des Moines to sustain themselves on gas station pizza; cover the Faith, Freedom, Family and Fudge Pops Forum; chase a long-shot presidential candidate who irons his own bluejeans; and huddle at a rotating cast of hotel bars each night.

title: The Breakaway Bride
description: When Susannah Cahalan, the author of the popular memoir Brain on Fire, shopped for a wedding dress late last year, she ventured well off the beaten path, stopping in at Stone Fox Bride for a cropped top and flowing skirt. Her chief consideration, she said, was that I be able to wear my dress more than one time.

title: In Myanmar, Military Action Forces Some to Flee: We Just Had to Run Away to Save Our Lives
description: The owner of a small grocery store in western Myanmar, Ko Thu Ya fled his home nearly three weeks ago with his family and has been on the run ever since.

title: A Little Variety
description: VARIETY PUZZLES  This weeks puzzles include:

title: Stark Choice for Syrians in Rebel Areas: Doom or the Green Bus
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The lime-green buses once ferried Syrians to school, work and dates at Damascus cafes. Now they pull up at moments of defeat, when rebel fighters and civilians, besieged and bombarded, give up their territory to government forces and board the vehicles en route to an uncertain future.

title: Donald Trump Kicks In $10 Million to Campaign
description: Donald J. Trump contributed another $10 million to his presidential campaign on Friday, providing a needed financial boost to his bid at a critical juncture.

title: Farhad and Mikes Week in Tech: Microsoft, Apple and Halloween!
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: Josh Tomlin Found Inspiration in Opponents Stands
description: CHICAGO  Josh Tomlin, the Cleveland Indians starting pitcher on Friday night, looked into the stands at Wrigley Field before the biggest game of his life and spotted his mother and father.

title: Can You Hire the Super for Odd Jobs?
description: For decades, shareholders in my co-op in Morningside Heights, Manhattan,  have hired building maintenance staff to do private handyman jobs on their own time, like installing shelving and making repairs. Last summer, the co-op board changed the house rules. Building employees can no longer do such jobs because of concerns about liability and misuse of co-op time. Many shareholders are upset. Can co-ops dictate what employees do in their private time and whom shareholders hire?

title: Clevelands Unthinking Racism
description: For many of Clevelands passionate, patient baseball fans, their teams logo is a joyful connection to the past. Its a reminder of the players from their childhood and from generations earlier. The logo  which was the centerpiece of a 28-foot-high sign that welcomed fans to Clevelands old ballpark for many seasons  is one of the few constants across the decades.

title: Greek Homeowners Scramble as Repossession Looms: Its Like a Horror Movie
description: ATHENS  Even after retiring as an accountant, Michalis Hanis dutifully kept up with the mortgage payments on the small house in a suburb of Athens where he has lived for 23 years. That was until several years ago, when Greeces economic crisis hit.

title: Javier Baez Is Conquered, This Time, in a Game Bursting With Pressure
description: CHICAGO  The World Series is a dragon that can consume the young and inexperienced, even the acolytes blessed with a profusion of talents.

title: Antique Teddy Bears and an Artists Trash: An Art Dork in Her Element
description: Emily Weiss, 30, is a senior account executive at DeWitt Stern, an insurance brokerage firm in New York

title: With City of Towers, China Puts Its Economic Stamp on Caucasus
description: TBILISI, Georgia  Scott Mi, a businessman from western China, stood on a balcony on one of the nine completed towers of 27 that his company plans to build and gestured toward the distant hilltop boundary of his improbable domain  a new, Chinese-built city rising atop one of the most volatile geopolitical fault lines left by the collapse of the Soviet Union.

title: Unhittable? Aroldis Chapman and His 105-M.P.H. Fastball
description: CHICAGO  Aroldis Chapman threw 13 pitches in his World Series debut on Wednesday in Cleveland. The fastest was clocked at 102.5 miles per hour by Major League Baseballs Statcast radar gun. The batter, Coco Crisp of the Indians, put it in play.

title: Popcast: Whats Next for Kesha?
description: The pop star has been locked in an ugly contract dispute with Dr. Luke; two writers who have examined her case break down the pop stars situation.

title: Seeking Clues to ISIS Strategy in Corpses and Cellphones Left in Kirkuk
description: KIRKUK, Iraq  Eighty-four bodies of Islamic State fighters were piled high at the Kirkuk hospital morgue, as the pathologists went through the gruesome work of gathering intelligence on the groups sudden counterattack on the city.

title: Whats Next for Kesha?
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Once again, we open by issuing an abject apology to a large group of people occupying a land mass, due to the nature of the acrostic quote. Were sorry, Florida. But Ive been there, and you do have insects the size of Buicks.

title: Doubts About the Promised Bounty of Genetically Modified Crops
description: LONDON  The controversy over genetically modified crops has long focused on largely unsubstantiated fears that they are unsafe to eat.

title: Broken Promises of Genetically Modified Crops
description: About 20 years ago, the United States and Canada began introducing genetic modifications in agriculture. Europe did not embrace the technology. This is how it has played out.

title: A Scandal Too Far? Huma Abedin, Hillary Clinton, and a Test of Loyalty
description: In the summer of 2013, Hillary Clinton had just left the State Department and returned to New York. She planned a quiet year, basking in sky-high approval ratings and enjoying a respite from the media spotlight as she laid the groundwork for a second presidential run.

title: On the Trail: Week of Oct. 23
description: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump campaigned in swing states, and Mrs. Clinton turned 69 on Wednesday, two days before the F.B.I. added a chapter to her email case.

title: Justice Dept. Strongly Discouraged Comey on Move in Clinton Email Case
description: WASHINGTON  The day before the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, sent a letter to Congress announcing that new evidence had been discovered that might be related to the completed Hillary Clinton email investigation, the Justice Department strongly discouraged the step and told him that he would be breaking with longstanding policy, three law enforcement officials said on Saturday.

title: Hillary Clinton Assails James Comey, Calling Email Decision Deeply Troubling
description: Hillary Clinton and her allies sprang onto a war footing on Saturday, opening a ferocious attack on the F.B.I.s director, James B. Comey, a day after he disclosed that his agency was looking into a potential new batch of messages from her private email server.

title: Jets Look to Recapture Passing Magic
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Brandon Marshall strode into the Jets locker room Wednesday wearing a green T-shirt featuring the bearded outline of a familiar face. It belonged to the Jets once and future quarterback, Ryan Fitzpatrick.

title: Who Owns Cheerleader Uniform Designs? Its up to the Supreme Court
description: The Supreme Court will spend part of Halloween hearing arguments about fashion, in a case that aims to determine whether anyone can own the stripes on cheerleader uniforms.

title: Pashtanas Lesson
description: When I first met Pashtana, she was a 15-year-old in the seventh grade  the oldest student in her classroom. She was caught in the awkward moment between being a girl and becoming a woman, and not quite comfortable in either role. But she was an eager class clown.

title: APTN, a TV Voice for Largely Ignored Indigenous Canadians
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba  The days top news stories are beamed from a round studio that evokes a tepee. Adventurous chefs teach viewers how to hunt, skin and cook beaver in a stew. Cartoons about a powerful superhero are broadcast in the Algonquin language.

title: N.F.L. Offenses Are Changing, So Some Offensive Linemen Are Shrinking
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Joe Berger remembers the feeling. It was February 2005 and Berger, along with hundreds of other N.F.L. hopefuls, was at the combine, the leagues annual scouting carnival. Many of the players were nervous or anxious, fretting about their bench-press repetitions or their sprint times. Berger, on the other hand, mostly felt bloated.

title: No Concession, No Sleep: Glued to the TV on Election Night 1960
description: The contest between Senator John F. Kennedy and Vice President Richard M. Nixon on Tuesday, Nov. 8, 1960, was expected to be close, and Americans were glued to their televisions until long after dawn. Coverage of the changing returns revealed some of the stresses and growing pains of early television news, which was little more than a decade old at the time.

title: Populist Wave Likely to Lift Icelands Pirate Party
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  Spain has Podemos. Italy has its Five Star Movement, and Greece its Syriza. Now, the populist insurgency sweeping through Europe is finding a foothold in Iceland, where the Pirate Party, with its pirate flag logo and anarchist leanings, is poised to make big gains in a general election on Saturday.

title: The Need for Financial Literacy
description: To the Editor:

title: What Wells Fargo Must Do
Trump and the Conservationist
25 Benjamins for Hamilton
Increase in Health Act Premiums May Affect Arizona Vote
description: PHOENIX  Arizona was shaping up to be one of the more unlikely battlegrounds of the 2016 campaign when a political bombshell appeared to explode last week: The Obama administration revealed that the cost of midlevel plans on the Affordable Care Acts health insurance marketplace here would increase next year by 116 percent on average.

title: N.S.A. Appears to Have Missed Big Red Flags in Suspects Behavior
description: WASHINGTON  Year after year, both in his messy personal life and his brazen theft of classified documents from the National Security Agency, Harold T. Martin III put to the test the governments costly system for protecting secrets.

title: Singing Hillary Clintons Praises, in Morgan Freemans Voice
description: Hillary Clinton, looking to close her general election campaign against Donald J. Trump by establishing a strong contrast with her opponent, is out with a new ad titled Example, which highlights her experience and criticizes his temperament.

title: At Yale, Theo Epstein Made a Splash as Newspapers Sports Editor
description: CHICAGO  As fans poured into the Yale Bowl for the 1993 football game with Harvard, a traditional season finale that embodies Ivy League rivalry, a provocative issue of The Yale Daily News circulated in the crowd.

title: Comey, Clinton and This Steaming Mess
description: Bigger than Watergate! Donald Trump exulted about the discovery of new emails from Hillary Clintons time as secretary of state. Sure, they could be. They could also be pleas from Clinton that Huma Abedin fetch her a skinny latte from Starbucks. We dont know. And the horrifying thing is that the F.B.I. director, James Comey, didnt seem to know, either, even as he disclosed their existence to the world.

title: A Back Door Into the Marathon Connects Runners With a Cause
description: When Katie Quan received an email informing her that she had not been selected in the lottery for the 2016 New York City Marathon, she was disappointed but not surprised. After all, the competition to secure a spot in the race is always intense: This year, only about one in four runners (19,083 out of 82,172) was selected in the drawing.

title: Nudges That Help Struggling Students Succeed
description: When I was in high school, I earned As in all my math classes  until I took calculus. In algebra and geometry, I could coast on memorizing formulas, but now I had to think for myself.

title: Poverty in Unexpected Places
description: Grinding poverty in the United States has long been synonymous with the Deep South, where low wages, poor health and diminished opportunity are more pervasive than in other parts of the country.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Agreed: Serve Your Time, Cast Your Ballot
description: The bitterly fought presidential campaign has underscored yet again that conservative and liberal Americans are deeply divided on just about every aspect of social policy.

title: How to Make Sense of College Rankings
description: Willard Dix is one of the crankiest observers of the college admissions process I know; hes also one of the smartest. He worked at Amherst, his alma mater, then advised college-bound students at a private secondary school in Chicago. He now blogs about higher education.

title: The Dangers of Donald Trump
description: IN last Sundays column, I wrote about the dangers that a Hillary Clinton presidency poses for the country. Since this is the final week for Hillary skeptics to agonize over whether to cast a vote for Donald Trump, it seems appropriate to outline why the risks of Trump are so distinctive as to throw the perils of a Clinton presidency into relative eclipse.

title: The Ethics of Hunting Down Patient Zero
description: The alleged Patient Zero of the American AIDS epidemic  a French Canadian flight attendant named Gatan Dugas, who died of AIDS in 1984  was exonerated last week.

title: Waking Up to Shorter Commutes
description: This could be a record year for transportation ballot proposals, because local politicians and voters have realized that Congress is not coming to rescue Americas aging bridges, roads and transit systems. On Nov. 8, there will be about 45 ballot proposals across the country that could raise nearly $200 billion for transportation improvements.

title: Husbands With Guns
description: We were still married then. It was 2008, and we bought an abandoned farmstead in the mountains of North Carolina, on the backside of Tennessee. We loved its 300-year-old trees  enormous white oaks with great gnarled arms  and my husband loved that it was off the grid.

title: 2008 Was a Celebration. 2016 Is the Opposite.
description: On Nov. 4, 2008, I was 26 years old and had just started working on an oral history project at a museum in Brooklyn. A co-worker and I were asked to interview people at polling places, to memorialize their thoughts about an election that might put the first African-American president in the White House.

title: Push to Tweak Time Zone Gains Momentum in Spain
description: MADRID  The Rodgers and Hart song I Didnt Know What Time It Was has nothing to do with time zones, but it may soon resonate for many Spaniards.

title: Peter Thiel Defends His Most Contrarian Move Yet: Supporting Trump
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Peter Thiel likes to take the path not taken. He has paid students to drop out of college, thinks Silicon Valley is overrated, backed a plan to build cities on the high seas and helped propel an electronic form of money into general use. His contrarian approach to investing and to life has made him rich and celebrated.

title: Rangers Jimmy Vesey Shows His Skill, and Toughness
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Jimmy Vesey scored the fourth goal of his fledgling N.H.L. career for the Rangers on Wednesday night, but Boston Bruins forward David Pastrnak crosschecked him into the end boards before Vesey had much of a chance to celebrate.

title: Mariano Rajoy Re-elected as Spains Prime Minister
description: MADRID  Mariano Rajoy was re-elected as Spains prime minister on Saturday, ending a bitter period of political deadlock.

title: In Defense of Politics, Now More Than Ever
description: ONE of John F. Kennedys favorite books was John Buchans 1940 memoir, Pilgrims Way. Buchan, who served as a member of Parliament for the combined Scottish universities, wrote, Public life is regarded as the crown of a career, and to young men it is the worthiest ambition. Politics, he added, is still the greatest and most honorable adventure.

title: America, Your Election Is Not Rigged
description: For the last few weeks, the Republican nominee for president, Donald J. Trump, has been talking a lot about how the Nov. 8 election is rigged against him. In fact, he sounds convinced that the entire campaign season is rigged in favor of his Democratic opponent, Hillary Clinton. These are serious charges, or they would be if Mr. Trump had any idea what he was talking about.

title: WikiLeaks Lays Bare a Clinton Insiders Emphatic Cheers and Jeers
description: In one note, Neera Tanden groused that whoever had let Hillary Clinton use a private email address for her State Department correspondence should be drawn and quartered.

title: How Hillary Clinton Met Satan
description: It was my third day at the Republican National Convention in 1996, and my notebook overflowed with a one-note theme: You do know that Hillary Clinton is funding the whole radical feminist agenda? She had Vince Foster killed. Shes behind many more murders than that. Its well-established that Hillary Clinton belonged to a satanic cult, still does. The consensus among Pat Buchanans supporters seemed ardent and universal, though the object of this obloquy wasnt even on the opposing ticket.

title: Richer but Not Better Off
description: It has been a long, painful slog out of the Great Recession. More than seven years into a halting recovery, fewer than 60 percent of working-age Americans hold a job  not much more than at the trough of the recession in the spring of 2009.

title: I Registered to Vote... For This?
description: Earlier this month, the United States hit a new benchmark in an already historic presidential campaign: For the first time in the countrys history, 200 million Americans are registered to vote. Over the past eight years, more than 50 million people have registered. That could mean that more Americans are voting for the first time this year than ever before.

title: Why Trump Stays Afloat
description: In one of the most emotionally wrenching presidential races in living memory, Donald J. Trumps support is as level as a pond. In polls, it is holding steady around 41 percent, right where it was after the first debate in late September. This plateau has persisted through the second and third debates with his opponent, Hillary Clinton, and the revelation of his recorded boasts of sexual assault. Even the stunning public rebuke of Mr. Trump by the parents of the Iraq war hero Capt. Humayun Khan in late July was followed by a swing of just a few percentage points, quite small by historical standards. Why has Mr. Trumps support not collapsed further in the face of some fairly damning revelations?

title: Spains Bullfighting Fight
description: MADRID  When the Parliament of Catalonia, an autonomous region in northeastern Spain, solemnly banned bullfighting in 2010, it was not simply a victory for animal rights. There was a political angle, as well, involving a battle over regional and national identity.

title: Tal Afar, West of Mosul, Becomes Center of Battle for Influence in Iraq
description: ERBIL, Iraq  The city of Tal Afar, a former Ottoman outpost not far from Mosul that has a mostly ethnic Turkmen population and has been home to a corps of Islamic State leaders, on Saturday became the focus of a growing struggle between Turkey and Iran for influence in northern Iraq.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Michigan Defeats Michigan State in a Big Ten Mismatch
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  Everything seemed a touch muted, a bit awkward, in the state of Michigan this past week. The usual rancor on sports talk radio and in fan memes before the annual football game between Michigan and Michigan State was not overly heated.

title: An Engaged Electorate
description: Readers offer their ideas for increasing voter participation.

title: Tarred by Trump, Paul Ryan Tries to Safeguard Both Party and Job
description: MODESTO, Calif.  This should have been a victory lap for Speaker Paul D. Ryan. Summoned by his party to heal its fractious majority in the House, Mr. Ryan grudgingly agreed to lead. Asked by House members to help them win re-election, he raised money by the millions and traveled thousands of miles to campaign at their side.

title: Bossy vs. Buddy: Two Leadership Styles, Each With Its Place
description: Which is more important to your boss: to dominate people or to be liked by them?

title: How Important Is Art History in Todays Market?
description: Rembrandt weeps.

title: Two Candidates Vie for One House Seat (for the Fourth Time)
description: In 2014, I wrote an article about New Hampshires very swingy congressional districts. With the same Democrat and Republican facing off in the First District for the fourth  yes, fourth  time, I couldnt resist another visit.

title: Updates
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  We have a list theme today by Caleb Madison, and I got this one pretty quickly because I am a complete and total Mac fangirl, except for iTunes, which could certainly use some work.

title: Donald Trump Questions Veracity of Ballot Counting in Colorado
description: GOLDEN, Colo.  Donald J. Trump has found a new reason to question the legitimacy of the 2016 election  ballots  and he wasted little time here on Saturday before taking issue with the voting system in this largely vote-by-mail state.

title: Powder Tossed at Metropolitan Opera May Have Been Human Ashes, Police Say
description: An audience member at the Metropolitan Opera sprinkled a powdery substance  what the police said may have been the ashes of his mentor  into the orchestra pit during an intermission of a performance on Saturday, setting off a police investigation and the cancellation of the rest of that opera and a production that evening.

title: Clintons Did Not Obtain Permits to Renovate Their New Chappaqua Home, Records Show
description: It is a necessary evil for any homeowner: a visit to the town building office to obtain the proper permits for upgrades.

title: Indians Closer Cody Allen Takes His Game to Another Level
description: CHICAGO  The Cleveland Indians have a custom: Whenever they sign a draft pick, they bring him to Cleveland and take him to dinner. Cody Allen, though, was in a hurry.

title: Knicks Let Lead Slip Against Grizzlies, but Still Hold On
description: The feting of the Knicks began early during their home opener against the Grizzlies at Madison Square Garden. As Joakim Noah celebrated and sneered in the second quarter, the fans chanted his name, prolonging each syllable. After a highlight-worthy dunk in the third, Kristaps Porzingis was met with a rousing ovation. When, moments later, Derrick Rose crossed over Mike Conley and then bounced off contact at the basket to finish a layup, there was ample applause.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Theres a longstanding policy of not doing anything that could influence an election. Those guidelines exist for a reason.

title: Indians Defeat Sloppy Cubs to Take a 3-1 World Series Lead
description: CHICAGO  All day long on the North Side of this baseball-obsessed city, fans in blue Cubs sweatshirts and caps moved nervously about town. There was still a festive buzz and a sense of excitement, but it was cut with a palpable edginess.

title: Rebecca Salman, Michael Lukach
description: Rebecca Michelle Salman, a daughter of Dr. Debra G. Salman and Dr. Richard A. Salman of Morganville, N.J., was married Oct. 29 to Michael James Lukach, a son of Patricia M. Lukach and William J. Lukach of Uniontown, Pa., at the Nassau Inn in Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Bill Kurry officiated.

description: Hannah Jewel Edelman, a daughter of Cindy R. Edelman and Glen S. Edelman of Melville, N.Y., was married Oct. 29 to Michael Scott Cromer, a son of Marilyn B. Cromer and Daniel M. Cromer of Miami. Rabbi Judith L. Siegal officiated at the One Hotel in Miami Beach.

description: Dana March and David Randolph Palmer were married Oct. 29 at Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Pocantico Hills, N.Y. Christopher Schroeder, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the groom, officiated.

title: Sophia Peters, Andrew Christensen
description: Sophia Cristina Peters and Andrew Jay Christensen were married Oct. 29 in Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. David A. Slagle Peck, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the Woodend Sanctuary of the Audubon Naturalist Society.

title: Katie Levy, Ezra Levine
description: Katie Rose Levy, the daughter of Janet M. Levy and Gary S. Levy of New York, was married Oct. 29 to Ezra Stahl Levine, a son of Gina Stahl Levine and Rabbi Robert N. Levine, also of New York. The groom's father led the ceremony, with Cantor Rebecca Garfein participating, at the Seawane Club, a golf and country club in Hewlett Harbor, N.Y.

title: Hillary Busis, Michael Palmieri
description: Hillary Brooke Busis, a daughter of Cynthia D. Shapira of Fox Chapel, Pa., and Dr. Neil A. Busis of Pittsburgh, was married Oct. 29 to Michael Stephen Palmieri, the son of Denise S. Palmieri and Michael J. Palmieri of Brooklyn, at the Ace Hotel in Pittsburgh. Rabbi Art Donsky officiated, with the Rev. David Poecking, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: Alexis Tarbet, Dominic Rinaldi

Rinaldi and Robert J. Rinaldi of Cincinnati. Don Winslow, a friend of the brides family who was designated a deputy marriage commissioner by San Diego County, officiated at Leo Carrillo Ranch in Carlsbad, Calif.

Donald Tierney of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Jason Brauninger, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Assumption Catholic Church in Chicago.

title: Lindsey Randolph, John Walsh
description: Lindsey Anne Randolph and John Clark Walsh were married Oct. 29. The Rev. Dr. J. Clayton Oliphint performed the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church in Richardson, Tex., where he is the senior pastor.

title: Gregory Colon, Jeremy Eggleston
description: Gregory Alexander Colon and Jeremy Joseph Eggleston were married Oct. 29. Rabbi Robert dos Santos Teixeira officiated in a ceremony including Christian and Muslim elements at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J.

title: Melissa Barry, Matthew Cantor
description: Melissa Brett Barry, a daughter of Jill M. Barry and Richard W. Barry of Roslyn Heights, N.Y., was married Oct. 29 to Matthew Bryan Cantor, a son of Bonnie M. Cantor of Pleasant Valley, N.Y., and Jay S. Cantor of Fishkill, N.Y. Rabbi Michael White officiated at Weylin B. Seymours, an event space in Brooklyn.
