description: Jennifer Erin Toyzer, a daughter of Gwen Toyzer of Havertown, Pa., and Dr. Barry J. Toyzer of Wynnewood, Pa., was married Oct. 29 to Alex Geoffrey Rothberg, the son of Sheila B. Alderman and Henry B. Rothberg of Jupiter Island, Fla. Rabbi George Scott Matous officiated at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn.

title: Catherine McKenzie, Carter Williams
description: Catherine Dewey McKenzie, the daughter of Catherine Daniel McKenzie and D. Ray McKenzie Jr. of LaGrange, Ga., was married Oct. 29 to Carter Ferguson Williams, a son of Helene H. Williams of Birmingham, Mich., and R. Jamison Williams of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The Rev. Dr. David A. Williams, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Trinity United Methodist Church in Charleston, S.C.

title: Nicole Rudolph, Nicholas Caputo
description: Nicole Alexis Rudolph, the daughter of Stephanie M. Rudolph of Wilmington, Del., was married Oct. 29 to Dr. Nicholas Dino Caputo, a son of Anna M. Anderson of Lake Grove, N.Y., and Frank A. Caputo of Smithtown, N.Y. The Very Rev. Gabriel Rach, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove, N.Y.

title: Jenna Heller, Matthew Rubin
description: Jenna Sara Heller, the daughter of Wendy Block Heller and Dan P. Heller of Pinecrest, Fla., is to be married Oct. 30 in New York to Matthew David Rubin, a son of Roberta L. Rubin of Wayne, N.J., and a stepson of the late Robert N. Ross. Rabbi Lawrence Hajioff, a friend of the couple, is to lead the ceremony at the Museum of Jewish Heritage in Battery Park.

title: Lydia Williams, Parry Sorensen
description: Lydia Marie Williams, a daughter of Elena Arana Williams and Dr. Gregory S. Williams of Villanova, Pa., was married Oct. 29 to Parry Daniel Sorensen, the son of Mary E. Sorensen and Richard P. Sorensen of North Caldwell, N.J. The Rev. Timothy L. Morehouse, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Merion Golf Club in Ardmore, Pa.

title: Emily Polsby, Christopher Mullin
description: Emily Polsby and Christopher Moyse Mullin are to be married Oct. 30. William A. Archbold, a Universal Life minister and a cousin of the groom, is to officiate at the Rockefeller Lodge in San Pablo, Calif., with Carla A. Cassler, a friend of the brides family, leading the seven blessings, a traditional Jewish element of a wedding ceremony.

title: Maureen Singer, David Harrell
description: Maureen Eugenia Singer and David Lin Harrell were married Oct. 29 at the Yale Club of New York. The Rev. Vince Corso, a minister with the International Council of Community Churches, officiated.

title: Peipei Zhou, Ian Saville
description: Peipei Zhou and Ian Dougal Saville are to be married Oct. 30 in Brooklyn. Dr. Aris H. Oates, who joined the American Marriage Ministries to preside at the ceremony, is to officiate at the Brooklyn Winery.

title: Sarah Magida, Chase Foster
description: Sarah Rachel Magida and Charles Warren Foster are to be married Oct. 30 at the Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Robert Orkand and Rabbi Lewis Kamrass will lead the ceremony.

title: Tess Golden, Dimitri Wohns
description: Tess Iphigene Golden, the daughter of Trudy Anna Legge Golden and Arthur Golden of Brookline, Mass., was married Oct. 29 to Dimitri Kolin Funch Wohns, a son of Wendelin Funch Wohns and Dr. David H.W. Wohns of Grand Rapids, Mich. Sage Wohns, a Universal Life minister who is a first cousin of the groom, led the ceremony at the Barn at Tyge William Cellars, an event space in Sonoma, Calif.

title: Trevor Hardwick, Stephen Flaherty
description: Trevor Hardwick and Stephen Charles Flaherty were married Oct. 26 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Angel L. Lopez, a staff member in the office of the City Clerk, officiated.

title: Corrections: October 30, 2016
description: SPORTS

title: Whats on TV Sunday: 100th Episode of Elementary and Oasis: Supersonic
description: Elementary celebrates a milestone by exploring outer space. Oasis: Supersonic follows the squabbling brothers and bandmates Liam and Noel Gallagher during their heyday in the 1990s. And the Richard Tucker Opera Gala will stream live from Carnegie Hall.

title: A Narrow Path of Hope Remains for the Cubs
description: CHICAGO  If the Chicago Cubs rally to win this World Series, the degree of difficulty will make the victory even sweeter. They would need to win three in a row from the Cleveland Indians, including two on the road, to make it happen.

title: South Korean President Dismisses Aides in Bid to Stem Worsening Scandal
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The shadowy woman at the center of President Park Geun-hyes worst political scandal apologized on Sunday for her wrongdoings. Hours later, Ms. Park fired her chief of staff and seven other presidential aides in an effort to regain public trust, a day after thousands of South Koreans took to the streets to call for her removal from office.

title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: 20 South Drive, Hastings-on-Hudson

title: Fire, Film, Tweet: The Talibans New Way of War
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban fighters posed for the camera, their shawls and bandannas covering their identities but not their jubilation, as they captured the main roundabout in the northern Afghan city of Kunduz early this month in what could have been called operation hoist the flag and pull out a smartphone.

title: Italy, Already Rattled, Is Struck by Another Powerful Quake
description: ROME  An earthquake, believed to be the strongest to hit Italy since 1980, struck the center of the country on Sunday, four days after two back-to-back quakes severely damaged buildings and left thousands homeless in the area. The temblor on Sunday also caused fresh damage to the towns destroyed by a quake that killed nearly 300 people in August.

title: Airstrikes by Saudi-Led Coalition Kill Dozens in Western Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  Dozens of people, including many prisoners, were killed after airstrikes by a Saudi-led military coalition struck a security facility in western Yemen, local security officials and news reports said on Sunday.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories, and a look ahead.

title: Latest Upshot Poll Shows Trump With a Lead in Florida
description: He has no plausible path to the presidency without Floridas 29 electoral votes, which is not true of Hillary Clinton.

title: College Is the Goal: Will These Teenagers Get There?
description: Is Zacs contrarian side holding him back? Should Nate choose the Ford dealership or architecture? Will harsh financial reality catch up with TaTy? The Times is following three teenagers in Topeka, Kan., on their quest to go to college.

title: Xi Jinping Is Chinas Core Leader: Heres What It Means
description: BEIJING  Chinas president, Xi Jinping, got a lift when the Communist Party gave him the title of core leader at a party meeting last week. But what does that mean for Mr. Xi and Chinas political future?

title: Icelands Prime Minister Resigns, After Pirate Party Makes Strong Gains
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  Icelands prime minister announced on Sunday that he would resign, as the insurgent, anti-establishment Pirate Party capitalized on a wave of anger over corruption to come in second place in the countrys general election.

title: Seeking Lower Rent, Chinese Artists Cut Path for Themselves Outside Beijing
description: YANJIAO, China  Artists in need of cheap, affordable studio space are often drawn to out-of-the-way or hardscrabble neighborhoods. The visual artists who flocked to SoHo in Manhattan decades ago helped resurrect what had been a deteriorating factory and warehouse district.

title: On Clinton Emails, Did the F.B.I. Director Abuse His Power?
description: THE F.B.I. is currently investigating the hacking of Americans computers by foreign governments. Russia is a prime suspect.

title: For Some in Syria, Buses Herald Doomsday
description: Thousands of opposition supporters have been forced to leave their cities as part of a deal with the Syrian government, boarding green buses that once symbolized a step toward modernization in Syria. The tactic has been used to transfer control of contested areas in the country's civil war.

title: Canada and E.U. Sign Trade Deal, Bucking Resistance to Globalization
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union and Canada signed a far-reaching trade agreement on Sunday that commits them to opening their markets to greater competition, after overcoming a last-minute political obstacle that reflected the growing skepticism toward globalization in much of the developed world.

title: One of the Last 3-Card Monte Dealers Declares Game Over
description: Ladies and gentlemen, I am Sylvester the eye-tester! a man whose real name is Andrew Jones bellowed in an outdoor plaza in the Bronx last week. For all of you who have not had your eyes tested in the last year or so, I am here for you!

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: My University Is on Fire
description: JOHANNESBURG  The university where I work is in crisis. Campuses across South Africa are on fire  in some cases literally  as students protesting impossibly high fees lock horns with reckless police officers. Students run a gantlet of rubber bullets, water cannons, stun grenades and tear gas just to make it to the library. Attendance has been sparse, with students, lecturers and other employees staying home in fear. Some universities have turned to overzealous police officers and the infamous private security industry in a bid to bring campuses under control.

title: For Democrats, Anthony Weiner Makes an Unwelcome Return
description: Carolyn B. Maloney, a congresswoman from the Upper East Side, was riding in a taxi on Friday when she heard the news: Emails discovered in an investigation into Anthony D. Weiners sexting had revived the F.B.I.s interest in the case of Hillary Clintons private server.

title: A Knicks Opponent Offers Derrick Rose a Low-Profile Role Model
description: Hey, Derrick Rose: Forget about Stephen Curry, Russell Westbrook, Damian Lillard and the other volume-scoring point guards. At this stage of your career, on this particular team in New York, the guy you really want to be like is Mike.

title: Rebecca Meskin, Elan Blum
description: Rebecca Leigh Meskin and Elan Julius Blum were married Oct. 29 in New York. Rabbi Mendel Solomon officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers.

title: Its on the Nose: Turbulence Often Strikes the Trump-Pence Planes
description: Gov. Mike Pences rocky landing on Thursday night at La Guardia Airport  the campaign plane skidded off the runway, and emergency crews scrambled to the scene in a driving rain  certainly lends itself as an apt metaphor for Donald J. Trumps entire presidential run: chaotic, turbulent and skittering just on the edge of disaster.

title: A Lost Snippet of Film History, Found in a Home Movie Shot in 1964
description: It was a can of 16-millimeter film, one among many from long ago. Robert Anen, an aspiring film archivist on a summer internship, read the label  something about the New York Worlds Fair in 1964  and said to himself, My father went to that as a small child, so Ill take a look.

title: Competing Views on How to Regulate Illegal Migration
description: The Bracero Program, which drew hundreds of thousands of Mexican laborers to toil in American fields from 1942 to 1964, left a searing memory of injustice. The program has been blamed for depressing farm wages and abusing immigrant workers.

title: Protests Erupt in Morocco Over Fish Vendors Death in Garbage Compactor
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco  Protests erupted across Morocco over the weekend after the death of a fish vendor who, according to witnesses, was crushed by a compactor after he jumped into a garbage truck to retrieve his merchandise.

title: Taliban Gain Ground in Afghanistan as Soldiers Surrender Their Posts
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Besieged Afghan officials in the southern province of Oruzgan said on Sunday that scores of regular Afghan soldiers had surrendered in the past week to the Taliban, a trend also occurring recently in other provinces.

title: Inferno Is Director Ron Howards Fourth Domestic Flop
description: One of Hollywoods most established directors, Ron Howard, an Oscar winner in 2002 for A Beautiful Mind, came up dreadfully short  again  at movie theaters in the United States and Canada over the weekend. Meanwhile, a director at the start of his career, Barry Jenkins, blew off the art-house doors with his Moonlight.

title: 10 Questions (and Answers) About New Email Trove
description: WASHINGTON  Just days before Election Day, and with voters in many states already going to the polls, the F.B.I. director made a stunning announcement on Friday: Agents had discovered new emails that might be relevant to the completed investigation into Hillary Clintons private server, a case that she had seemingly put behind her in July.

title: World Series Ticket to Wrigley Fulfills a 71-Year-Old Promise by Brothers
description: CHICAGO  The boy stood on the corner of Division and Oakley on Chicagos North Side, tears trickling down his cheeks as his three older brothers boarded a streetcar bound for Wrigley Field.

title: Hillary Clinton Tries to Move Past Email Issue; Donald Trump Revels in It
description: Hillary Clinton worked to campaign past the revived controversy around her email server on Sunday, casting herself as a resilient fighter as Donald J. Trump intensified his sweeping claims of corruption in the American justice system.

title: U.S. Tells Families of Istanbul Consulate Staff to Leave Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  The State Department on Sunday ordered all members of the families of its consulate staff in Istanbul to leave Turkey, citing increased security threats from terrorist organizations.

title: Medias Odd Couple: Proudly Freewheeling HBO and Buttoned-Up AT&T
description: Can an elite, free-spending TV network based in Manhattan find a comfortable home at a Dallas telecommunications company led by an executive who is also the Boy Scouts of America president?

title: Ecstatic Music Festival at Merkin Hall to Feature Vijay Iyer and Others
description: The seventh annual Ecstatic Music Festival will begin in January at Merkin Concert Hall and feature performances from Vijay Iyer, San Fermin and Roomful of Teeth.

title: On a Long Island Burial Ground: 47 Gravestones, 1,700 Graves
description: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y.  There are 47 tombstones and 24 footstones in a two-acre cemetery in the middle of a residential neighborhood here.

title: Clinton, Mosul, Pirate Party: Your Monday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: A Times Intern Connects With a Muslim Family in Staten Island
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this article, Samantha Schmidt, an intern with the metro section, reflects on what her brief immersion in the life of one Staten Island family taught her about the challenges of being a Muslim parent in America.

title: Heng on Pakistans Militant Insurgency
description: A recent attack showed that extremist groups remain a potent threat for the Pakistani military and security forces.

title: Jets Again Look All but Helpless, and Then the Second Half Starts
description: CLEVELAND  The Jets have treated crowds around the country to some hideous football, and after one of their most hideous halves of the season, played in a stadium that has hosted more hideous football than any other, they retreated to their locker room for a scolding  several, actually.

title: Review: The Alien Abductees of People of Earth Keep the Humor Grounded
description: Its only a mild spoiler to reveal that the main characters of the new TBS comedy People of Earth  members of an Alcoholics Anonymous-like support group for alien abductees  are actual alien abductees. Theyve seen the bright lights overhead and been sucked up into the hovering ship. And they all agree on one peculiar aspect of their experience: Before sending their captives back to Earth, the aliens took the trouble to tell them You. Are. Special.

title: Listening Clubs Tantalize Audiophiles in London
description: LONDON  One Sunday evening in September, the main hall of a community center here was decked out with ribbons, balloons and a gyrating disco ball that marked a sonic sweet spot  the optimal position for partygoers to enjoy the clean, punchy (and not too loud) sound of five towering speakers arranged strategically around the room, piping a playlist of pop, funk, rock and dance floor gems for all generations.

title: Review: Mark Morris Is a Citizen of the World at the White Light Festival
description: Because Mark Morris pays close attention to music in his choreography, you can hardly miss the sanity in his method. But his choice of movement often shows a streak of lunacy, a nave and eccentric singularity that makes you think, Who else in the world would have thought of something so completely nutty? Its this aspect of him that can seem magically inspired.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Oct. 31
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Review: Jenufa With Signature Vocals and a Really Big Rock
description: Its never easy to be a diva, but the Metropolitan Operas production of Janaceks Jenufa, a stirring revival of which opened on Friday, comes with a special challenge: A singer has to hold her own against the rock.

title: Newly Released Books
description: By Jade Chang

title: A Little-Noticed Fact About Trade: Its No Longer Rising
description: The constant flow of goods from Asia to the United States was briefly interrupted last month after Hanjin, the South Korean shipping line, filed for bankruptcy, stranding several dozen of its cargo ships on the high seas.

title: Opera Fans Last Wish Led to Terror Scare at the Met
description: No one had seemed more excited for the pair of Rossini operas at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday than Roger Kaiser, a Texas opera buff who, the police believe, inadvertently created a terrorism scare that forced the Met to cut its matinee short and cancel its evening performance.

title: Justice Department Obtains Warrant to Review Clinton Aides Emails
description: WASHINGTON  Federal investigators have obtained a warrant to begin searching a large cache of emails belonging to a top aide to Hillary Clinton, law enforcement officials said on Sunday, as prosecutors and F.B.I. agents scrambled under intense public pressure to assess their significance before Election Day.

title: Philip Guston and His Barbed-Pen Nixon Years
description: In the summer of 1971, the artist Philip Guston and the writer Philip Roth were refugees of a sort in Woodstock, N.Y. Mr. Roth was fleeing what he called his overnight notoriety as a sexual freak, after the publication of Portnoys Complaint. Guston, in a crisis of self-doubt, was turning his back on practically the entire art world.

title: Often Worn Backward
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Peter A. Collins is back and hes hearing echoes. At least it seems that way, since his theme has some repetition in it.

title: A Lingering, Deadly Legacy of Wars: Unexploded Bombs
description: The Vietnam War ended in 1975. It did for Americans anyway. Not so for the Vietnamese.

title: The Color Purple Is to Close in January
description: The Tony-winning revival of The Color Purple will close on Jan. 8 after a year of performances.

title: Defusing Wars Perfect Soldiers
description: In 1997, Princess Diana brought public attention to land mine victims. But, almost two decades after her death, how much progress has been made in the worldwide fight against leftover munitions?

title: Black Voters, Aghast at Trump, Find a Place of Food and Comfort
description: PHILADELPHIA  Natalie Solomon was always an early riser. Back in her days at a Ford-owned auto electronics plant, managing production schedules and bringing in $60,000 a year with overtime, she would be behind the wheel of her Ford Explorer by 4 a.m.  in time to grab coffee at Wawa, swing by her locker, grab her smock and get on the factory floor before 5.

title: Early Turnout Tilts Toward Democrats in Swing States
description: Hillary Clinton has established a slim edge over Donald J. Trump in early-voter turnout in several vital swing states, pressing her longstanding advantages in state-level organization and potentially mitigating the fallout from her campaigns latest scrap with the F.B.I.

title: Final Fed Meeting and Final Jobs Report Before Election Day
description: Heres a look at whats coming up this week:

title: Witchcraft on the Campaign Trail
description: The idea has been flying about for a while now, at least since the summers cries to lock up or hang the Democratic presidential candidate. Earlier on, Ben Carson helpfully linked her to Lucifer. After the first debate, Rush Limbaugh made the designation official: In a double-barreled attack, he declared that Hillary Clinton came off exactly as many people see her  a witch with a capital B.

title: World Series: Heres How the Chicago Cubs Won Game 5
description: Follow our live Game 6 coverage here.

title: Publishers Are Rethinking Those Around the Web Ads
description: You see them everywhere, and maybe, sometimes, you click: those rows of links under web articles, often augmented with eye-catching photos and curiosity-stoking headlines about the latest health tips, celebrity news or ways to escape financial stress.

title: Ikea Strategy Ditches the Dream Home for the Daily Grind
description: THE settings for the vignettes are workaday and unassuming: a living room where a man surrounded by file boxes and paperwork nods off on the sofa, a compact bedroom where two brothers very different personalities are on display, an apartment where a father tiptoes from a crib in the single bedroom to a loft bed in the living room.

title: Review: Canticles of the Holy Wind Summons the Elements at the Met
description: Its no wonder that birdsong should be central to the work of John Luther Adams, a composer and an environmental activist whose music often draws inspiration from the unspoiled Arctic wilderness that he has fought to preserve. Throughout the 70s he worked on songbirdsongs, a cycle that translates his field observations into crystalline instrumental miniatures for flutes and percussion. Later works sometimes incorporated ornithological quotations, like the different types of thrushes heard in A Northern Suite.

title: The Worlds Political Power Couples
description: Female heads of state or government are often members of political dynasties. Sometimes they follow their husbands into office, and occasionally their husbands follow them.

title: Wife and Running Mate: A Real-Life House of Cards in Nicaragua
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  She started out as a teenage mother working as a newspaper secretary, then spent decades of revolution, conflict, power and public scandal at the side of one of the regions most influential men.

title: The Stakes Are Rising in Googles Antitrust Fight With Europe
description: Google is locked in a six-year battle with Europe's antitrust officials. And the stakes for both sides are getting higher.

title: One-and-Done System Gets a Documentary. Call It a Farce.
description: When Ben Simmons was 14, growing up in Melbourne, Australia, his father turned on a video camera and asked him, If you had any choice in the world right now, where would you like to play?

title: Instant Karma on Columbus Avenue
description: Dear Diary:

title: 300 Million Children Breathe Highly Toxic Air, Unicef Reports
description: MUMBAI, India  About 300 million children in the world breathe highly toxic air, the United Nations Childrens Fund said in a report on Monday that used satellite imagery to illustrate the magnitude of the problem.

title: Bridge Scandal Has Become Thorny Issue for Another Governor: Cuomo
description: The monumental traffic jam at the foot of the George Washington Bridge was never supposed to be Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos problem.

title: Beyond Silicon: Squeezing More Out of Chips
description: SEATTLE  Ali Farhadi holds a puny $5 computer, called a Raspberry Pi, comfortably in his palm and exults that his team of researchers has managed to squeeze into it a powerful program that can recognize thousands of objects.

title: Six Concussions Later, Jordan Reed Fears Heartache of Losing Football
description: ASHBURN, Va.  Jordan Reed, the Washington Redskins tight end, said he felt better. So much better. The headaches are gone. The nausea, too. No more uncontrollable crankiness. No more lost sleep.

title: Seeking Ownership of Both the Information and the Superhighway
description: On the face of it, there is something Strangelovian about the proposed merger between AT&T and Time Warner.

title: As Health Premiums Jump, Obama Wields an Imperfect Shield
description: WASHINGTON  Urging people to sign up for coverage under the Affordable Care Act, President Obama said last week that while premiums might be rising, most consumers need not worry. Premiums going up, he said, dont necessarily translate into higher premiums for people who are getting tax credits.

title: Ari Shavit, Celebrated Israeli Columnist, Resigns After Sexual Harassment Accusations
description: JERUSALEM  The author Ari Shavit attained international celebrity with a deeply introspective look at Israels remarkable rise and its controversial moments. With passion and authority, he helped make it possible for many liberal supporters of Israel to admire the nation while questioning its policies.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: The October surprise doesnt mean anything. The bars been lowered so much, you cant lower it any more.

title: Con Ed Says Plan to Install Rooftop Solar Panels Will Aid Poor New Yorkers
description: More than 10,000 New York City residents are using solar power to reduce their electric bills. But hardly any of those people converting the suns rays into savings are poor.

title: No Corrections: October 31, 2016
description: No corrections appeared in print.

title: How Often Has Terry Francona Thought About His Legacy? Never
description: CHICAGO  Terry Francona ducked under a drain pipe and headed up the dank and narrow tunnel leading to the visitors clubhouse at Wrigley Field, the ancient baseball shrine. The clubhouse  any clubhouse  is his sanctuary, his favorite spot in the world, the place where he starts his day preparing for a game, well before his players arrive, so he can give them his full attention when they do.

title: Lessons From Europe on Using Contactless Cards
description: For banks and retailers, there is a fine line between making peoples use of credit and debit cards as painless as possible and protecting individuals financial details from swindlers.

title: Review: Les Liaisons Dangereuses Uses Sex as a Weapon
description: In the high-stakes sport of extreme stage acting, Janet McTeer and Liev Schreiber are champion cliff divers. Give them an emotional precipice to jump from, and theyll soar through the air and stick the landing.

title: The Walking Dead Season 7, Episode 2: Greetings From the Kingdom
description: Sorry about all the violence and death last week, Walking Dead fans. Here, have a tiger.

title: Westworld Season 1, Episode 5: The Search for Meaning
description: The paradox of Westworld as a theme park is that guests come seeking a taste of freedom  no laws, no standards of decency, no limits beyond the horizon  but are, in fact, submitting themselves to a world thats controlled, surveilled and quite literally programmed. Its a fantasy of Old West freedom, and a potent one for thrill-seekers who give themselves over to it passively, chasing their animal desire for realistic shoot-em-ups and readily available android sex. But the more time spent in Westworld, the more the seams begin to show, and the behavioral patterns and loops start to look just as mundane and predictable as the domestic routines theyve left behind.

title: Review: In Coriolanus, a Politician for a Campaign Season
description: You dont have to squint too hard to discern unsettling contemporary relevance in the Red Bull Theaters gripping new production of Shakespeares Coriolanus, which opened on Sunday at the Barrow Street Theater. The director, Michael Sexton, all but pulls out a pen and starts highlighting from the get-go.

title: W. Dudley Johnson, Heart Bypass Surgery Pioneer, Dies at 86
description: Dr. W. Dudley Johnson, who pioneered and popularized lifesaving cardiac bypass surgery and was considered a healer of last resort for heart patients around the world, died on Oct. 24 in Milwaukee. He was 86.

title: Pro-Russian Candidate Leads Moldova Presidential Vote but Faces Runoff
description: MOSCOW  In a blow to Western efforts to tug former Soviet lands out of Moscows orbit, a strong supporter of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia finished far ahead of pro-Western candidates in a presidential election on Sunday in Moldova.

title: Kris Bryant Takes Lessons From Ted Williamss Batting Bible
description: CHICAGO  Dig through a public library or the reference shelf of your neighborhood hitting coach, and you might find a relic. Decades before heat maps and swing paths became part of baseballs vernacular and the value of getting on base was truly embraced, Ted Williams laid out many of the hitting philosophies that are in vogue today. He did so in a book titled The Science of Hitting.

title: A Somber Charleston Reflects on Race as 2 Murder Trials Begin
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Seventy-four days separated the fatal bursts of gunfire: the eight rounds a white police officer fired at Walter L. Scott, a black man in North Charleston, and then the shots that killed nine black churchgoers at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church here.

title: Indians Starter Corey Kluber Emerges as a Postseason Powerhouse
description: CHICAGO  To properly appreciate the postseason of the Cleveland Indians ace Corey Kluber, first consider that only two other pitchers have started on short rest more than once in the same postseason over the past 10 years: C. C. Sabathia of the Yankees in 2009 and Clayton Kershaw of the Los Angeles Dodgers this year.

title: Insecure Season 1, Episode 4: Career Day
description: Episode 4 of Insecure feels, at first, like the most minor one yet. But if you peer closer, its looking at the same theme from different angles: the sharp divide between the life we dream of and the life were actually living. This is never more clear than when Daniel is in Issas orbit.

title: Leafs Phenom Auston Matthews Stirs Cheers in Islanders Building
description: Auston Matthews skated onto the Barclays Center ice Sunday, and Toronto fans  braving the pulsating pregame music and wearing his No. 34  broke into big smiles when they saw the teenage visitor.

His grave site, on the edges of a pond and shaded by leafy trees at Graceland Cemetery, was adorned Sunday with several bouquets of wilting red roses and yellow mums, and a small white towel emblazoned with a blue W.

title: New York Senate Debate Becomes Proxy War for Presidential Hopefuls
description: During a debate on Sunday, Senator Chuck Schumer of New York pronounced himself appalled  at least four times  that the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had disclosed that he was again looking into the matter of Hillary Clintons emails without yet knowing the significance of a newly discovered batch.

description: TOKYO  In a fresh sign of the economic fallout from weaker global trade, Japans three largest shipping companies agreed on Monday to merge a major portion of their businesses, saying they needed to join forces to survive.

description: James Galanos, a fashion designer who spent decades dressing Americas social elite, most notably Nancy Reagan, died on Sunday at his home in West Hollywood, Calif. He was 92.

description: Zhang Wei, Chinas top-earning online novelist, is not modest about his success. I love writing, and Im gifted, Mr. Zhang, 35, said in a recent interview.

title: Chicagos Grim Era of Police Torture
description: Americans who think of officially sanctioned torture as something that happens in other countries will be shaken when they confront the grim holdings of the Chicago Torture Archive, an online research repository set to open early next year. The archive  which includes testimony and documents from criminal trials and civil rights cases  was collected by the Peoples Law Office, which represented numerous survivors of police torture. The trove will give researchers chilling insight into the grisly period from the 1970s to the 1990s when the Chicago Police Departments infamous torture crew rounded up more than 100 African-American men who were shocked with cattle prods, beaten with telephone books and suffocated with plastic bags until many confessed to crimes.

title: Chavismo Full Circle
description: NEW ORLEANS  Venezuelas opposition movement is promising to follow its huge march last week with a march this week to the Presidential Palace to demand the restitution of the recently shut down recall referendum. The government of President Nicols Maduro has mobilized its followers to defend the revolution in the streets. It is a confrontation unlikely to have a happy ending.

description: When a previously unknown painting by a 17th-century Dutch master is authenticated by some of the finest curators and experts, sold for $10 million and then abruptly discovered to be a fake, questions arise. Many of them.

title: Working the Refs
description: The cryptic letter James Comey, the F.B.I. director, sent to Congress on Friday looked bizarre at the time  seeming to hint at a major new Clinton scandal, but offering no substance. Given what we know now, however, it was worse than bizarre, it was outrageous. Mr. Comey apparently had no evidence suggesting any wrongdoing by Hillary Clinton; he violated longstanding rules about commenting on politically sensitive investigations close to an election; and he did so despite being warned by other officials that he was doing something terribly wrong.

title: We Dont Need a War on Climate Change, We Need a Revolution
description: This year is on track to become the hottest ever recorded, and a growing number of environmentalists are using a particular type of language in response. Some are calling for a huge mobilization to combat climate change. In an article in the New Republic in August, Bill McKibben, the unofficial spokesperson of the climate movement in the United States, insisted in very literal terms that, we are at war with climate change.

title: Behind the Mask: Scenes From Nicaraguas Sandinista Revolution
description: A photo of three men wearing traditional Nicaraguan folk masks and holding homemade contact bombs graced the cover of The New York Times Magazine on July 30, 1978. Alan Ridings article, with photos by Susan Meiselas, chronicled the popular uprising against the dictatorship of Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

The court, which worked harder in those days, heard four arguments that Monday. The new justice, who had barely survived a brutal confirmation process, asked no questions.

title: Of Jacks and Jennets: Facts About Donkeys
description: There are about 44 million donkeys worldwide. They evolved from the African wild ass, which is critically endangered. As few as 600 may exist in Ethiopia, Eritrea and Somalia. Donkeys can live well into their 40s.

title: Pigeon: From the Wild to the French Table
description: In pursuit of the delicately gamy palombe, a rising favorite at top restaurants in Paris.

title: Hunting Pigeon in the Pyrenees  for Supper
description: FALL IS WILD GAME SEASON in France, and discerning diners at Parisian outposts like LAmi Jean, La Rgalade and Spring come especially for the composed dishes of just-hunted, rich-tasting game. That one might bite into ones mallard or grouse and land on stray birdshot is perhaps a badge of honor, proof that whats on your plate has a woodsier back story than the steak. And palombe, or wood pigeon, has a better back story than most. As a chef, you want something that tastes delicious, but also thats coherent and has its own tradition, says Daniel Rose, who serves it rare-roasted at his First Arrondissement restaurant Spring during the birds month-and-a-half season from mid-October to the end of November. Generally grayer than its close cousin, the standard pigeon, with distinctive white marks on its neck and wings, the wild-caught palombe is more delicately gamy and less rich. Rose serves his with braised foie gras and cabbage, and a pure of smoked beet. At LAmi Jean, Stphane Jgo goes a more traditional route, roasting the birds with thyme and garlic, or stewed in salmi, a mixture of giblets, wine and foie gras. Wild palombe brings a rustic, old-fashioned moment to the table, Rose notes. It evokes the deliciousness of nature and cooking on an open fire.

title: Making Sense of the Two Candidates Plans on Student Debt
description: If you use the Wayback Machine, a site that archives old versions of websites, to check out what Barack Obamas 2012 campaign had to say about making higher education more affordable, the answer is: not much.

title: Promoting Clinton, Obama Is a Snapchat Rarity: He Hopes His Message Lasts
description: WASHINGTON  Barack Obama, the first commander in chief to regularly send emails and to use Twitter and Facebook, has added another breakthrough to his technological legacy: first president of the United States to use Snapchat.

title: Bob Dylan Won. But in Science, the Times They Arent A-Changin.
description: When I first heard that Bob Dylan had won the Nobel Prize in Literature, I was immediately jealous of the scientists who had won this year. Not because they were now rich and had gained scientific immortality, but because they would get to meet the legendary troubadour himself at the festivities in Stockholm.

description: The stakes are rising for antitrust cases, especially in Europe. Margrethe Vestager, the European competition chief, has picked some high-profile fights with American companies.

title: Quoth the Vulture Nevermore
description: The rains weve been waiting for, yearning for, have finally arrived in our part of Tennessee, and the sugar-maple leaves are falling now in great clots. Rain is falling and leaves are falling and my youngest son, like his brothers, has received his Selective Service card in the mail, and today I have returned to my house to find a lone black vulture standing in my front yard.

The Bullpen Series
description: CHICAGO  This World Series was bound to be fascinating, if only for the history of the Chicago Cubs and the Cleveland Indians. The backdrop wrote itself: 176 combined seasons of consecutive misery for two franchises in bedrock major league towns.

title: General Electric Plans to Merge Its Oil and Gas Division With Baker Hughes
description: As oil and gas companies work their way through the worst slump in their industry in more than two decades, General Electric is making a huge move to bolster its own business that serves those companies.

title: No, Emailgate Is Not Worse Than Watergate
description: Donald J. Trump wasted no time in seizing on the unprecedented letter that the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, sent to Congress on Friday, regarding the bureaus investigations into Hillary Clintons emails. This is bigger than Watergate, Mr. Trumps team tweeted just a few hours after the letter was made public.

title: Michel Aoun Rises to Lebanese Presidency, Ending Power Vacuum
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Michel Aoun, a charismatic retired general, polarizing Christian politician and ally to Hezbollah, was chosen president of Lebanon on Monday morning, ending a two-and-a-half-year vacuum that had tested the countrys ability to function without political leadership.

title: Indians Goal Now: One Win in Cleveland
description: CHICAGO  Shortly after the Cleveland Indians lost Game 5 of the World Series, the teams starting pitcher in the game, Trevor Bauer, dutifully came back onto the field to conduct interviews. As he spoke in front of the visitors dugout at Wrigley Field, a loud fan yelled at Bauer, sarcastically thanking him for helping the Chicago Cubs to win.

title: R.I.P., Age of Fashion Division(s)
description: Last week, Sonia Rykiel, the French house owned by First Heritage Brands that has been undergoing something of a buzz renaissance under the designer Julie de Libran (though still struggling financially), announced it was incorporating its more affordable Sonia by Sonia Rykiel line into its main one, the better to rationalize the brand image and message to customers.

title: Eurozone Economy Grows Steadily, Albeit Slowly. What Now?
description: FRANKFURT  Amid myriad battles over trade agreements, concerns about the impending negotiations for Britains exit from the European Union, and political instability across the region, the eurozone continued to grow steadily but slowly in the third quarter.

title: Geert Wilders, Dutch Politician, Distracts From Hate-Speech Trial With More Vitriol
description: AMSTERDAM  The Dutch governments prosecution of a far-right lawmaker for hate speech was upstaged by his continued racial vitriol on Monday before the trial could get underway.

title: CenturyLink, a Network Provider, to Acquire Level 3, a Rival
description: To those familiar with the telecommunications industry, the deal announced between CenturyLink and Level 3 Communications on Monday was not really a surprise. Both companies provide communications and services like data, voice and video transmission for large enterprises and each is trying to scrape away market share from rivals AT&T and Verizon.

title: Judge Tells N.F.L. to Reveal Some Secrets About Concussions
description: A New York judge is forcing the N.F.L. to reveal something it has desperately tried to keep secret: how the leagues medical officials handled the issue of brain injuries over the last two decades.

title: Michael Golden, Vice Chairman of Times Co., to Retire
description: Michael Golden, the vice chairman of The New York Times Company, will retire from his executive management role at the end of the year, the company announced on Monday. He will continue to serve on the board.

title: 1916: Hindenburg Makes Boast on the War
description: Field-Marshal von Hindenburg has been interviewed at General Headquarters by a representative of the Vienna Neue Freie Presse. Questioned as to the military situation, he replied: It is as favorable as possible, and everything will continue to go well. But how long will the war last? asked the correspondent. That depends on our adversaries, said Hindenburg. It is useless to prophesy. In war time especially, it is preferable to abstain from doing so. It is possible that the year 1917 may bring about fighting which will decide the war. I can say nothing as to this, but what I can say is that we shall never give in until a decision is reached.

title: Was Alan Greenspan Motivated by Politics More Than Economics?
description: THE MAN WHO KNEWThe Life and Times of Alan GreenspanBy Sebastian MallabyIllustrated. 781 pp. Penguin Press. $40.

title: Trade Plateaus (Wonkish)
description: Binyamin Appelbaum has a nice piece about the stall in world trade growth, which I (and many others) have been tracking for a while. And I thought Id write a bit more about this, if only to serve as a much-needed distraction from the election.

title: What Do Clinton and Merkel Have in Common?
description: BERLIN  As a German, I guess its none of my business, but still  Im excited about Hillary Clinton. As a woman, I feel she is in there for me, too. If things go right, for the first time in history, a woman, one of us, will rule the world. Go, Hillary! Get us that job!

title: Kimmy Schmidts Tituss Burgess: My Presence Is Political
description: On Netflixs Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt, Tituss Burgess plays the hilarious, self-involved, sometimes cutthroat but always lovable Titus Andromedon. Titus is the roommate of the titular Kimmy, who recently escaped from a small-time cult leader who held her in an underground bunker.

title: With Dak Prescotts Cowboys Winning, Few Clamor for Romos Return
description: At the top of the quarterback categories this season, right around Tom Brady and Matt Ryan and Andy Dalton, theres a name that would have been unfamiliar to most pro football fans a year ago: Dak Prescott.

title: Opioid Poisonings Rise Sharply Among Toddlers and Teenagers
description: The number of children being hospitalized because of prescription opioid poisoning has risen sharply since 1997, especially among toddlers and older teenagers, researchers from the Yale School of Medicine reported.

title: Noam Chomsky and the Bicycle Theory
description: At 87, Noam Chomsky, the founder of modern linguistics, remains a vital presence in American intellectual life. An emeritus professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he still teaches, he has a dual identity, reflected in his several dozen books. Many are on theoretical linguistics and the philosophy of mind. Others are sharp, leftish polemics on American politics. Dr. Chomsky is back in the news, thanks to a pair of high-profile attacks. In The Kingdom of Speech, Tom Wolfe pairs Dr. Chomsky (Noam Charisma) with Darwin as the malign Ur-theorists of evolution. In Decoding Chomsky: Science and Revolutionary Politics, the British anthropologist Chris Knight explores the Chomsky problem  the paradox of a thinker who belongs to the professional and scientific elite even as he espouses populist political ideas.

title: TeamHealth Agrees to Be Sold to Blackstone
description: Almost exactly a year ago, TeamHealth Holdings, a provider of physician outsourcing services, rebuffed a takeover offer from its rival AmSurg for nearly $8 billion, saying the proposed valuation was too low.

title: Alterra America Insurance v. National Football League
description: Justice Jeffrey Oing's ruled on an issue that is central to whether the insurers will pay for a class-action settlement brought by more than 5,000 retired players who accused the N.F.L. of fraud and negligence.

title: Turkey Detains Prominent Opposition Journalists
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish authorities detained the editor and several prominent writers of one of the countrys few remaining opposition newspapers on Monday, a day after the government dismissed 10,000 civil servants suspected of links to a failed coup in July.

title: Meet the Leading Expert on American Political Leaders Health, and His West Wing Doppelgnger
description: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times. In this piece, Lawrence K. Altman, M.D.  a physician journalist whose Times interview with Ronald Reagan in 1980 about the then-presidential candidates health is believed to be the first of its kind  ruminates on his experience chronicling would-be leaders fitness for office from the 70s to the present.

title: College Is the Goal: Will These Teenagers Get There?
description: The Times is following three teenagers in Topeka, Kan., on their quest to go to college. But what is the value of a college education today? Is it the answer to income inequality and the lack of class mobility in America?

title: Recipe Treats, No Tricks
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Nonprofits to Help Boston Globe Pay Classical Music Critic
description: As media coverage of classical music continues a decades-long diminuendo across the United States, The Boston Globe is trying something new: On Monday it announced a pilot program in which a consortium of nonprofit groups would help it pay for a critic.

title: The World Series at Wrigley
description: A city of characters showed up en masse to cheer for the home team.

title: My Life in Pictures: Kenneth Jay Lane
description: For six decades, he has created exquisite jewelry, all of it fake.

title: The Sparkling Life and (Fake) Jewelry of Kenneth Jay Lane
description: He made costume jewelry chic, but he is just as famous for his glittering social life.

title: A Numberplay Farewell
description: This  after seven years  is my last Numberplay column for The Times. Its been a terrific, wild ride, full of new friendships and rewarding discovery. But its now time to focus on new projects: teaching a course on the art of logic in Shanghai, developing an online program on the psychology of reasoning at Stanford and helping to create a national math tournament in Nigeria.

title: Two Books Unlock the Secrets of Spice
description: Two of the citys best spice purveyors now have reference guides. Padma Lakshmi, the television personality and cookbook author, has collaborated with Kalustyans, a magic carpet of ingredients on Lexington Avenue and 29th Street, on an A-to-Z guide to spices and herbs. Color photos illustrate many of the entries and typical uses, but no recipes are given. Lior Lev Sercarz, who owns La Bote, a spice shop on 11th Avenue and 51st Street, and who custom-blends spices for chefs, has also done a guide. The handsome book comes in a box, is lavishly photographed and is organized alphabetically to cover spices and herbs. There are no recipes, but suggested uses are given for each product. Mr. Sercarz explains how to best buy, blend, roast and store seasonings, and how spices are sanitized to be sold: The Encyclopedia of Spices & Herbs: An Essential Guide to the Flavors of the World, by Padma Lakshmi with Judith Sutton and Kalustyans (Harper Collins, $25); The Spice Companion: A Guide to the World of Spices, by Lior Lev Sercarz (Clarkson Potter, $40, $50 with slipcase).

title: German E.U. Official Is in Trouble Over Remarks About Chinese
description: BERLIN  One of the most powerful people in Brussels, Gnther Oettinger, has come under fire for reportedly referring to Chinese people as slit-eyes and sly dogs in a speech to business leaders in Hamburg.

title: Cornrows? No. Superheroes? Yes.
description: (Race/Related is a weekly newsletter exploring race and ethnicity. Sign up.)

title: A Brandy for the Last Whig President
description: The folks at Germain-Robin, a craft distillery in Northern California, honored the 13th president of the United States, Millard Fillmore, with their latest brandy because, like American brandies, they consider him to be not very well known or appreciated. I confess little knowledge of President Fillmore, the last Whig Party president (1850 to 1853), but I have been an admirer of the Cognac-style brandies the company keeps producing. You may call this new one an entry-level brandy, a gentle blend that delivers smooth, floral and dried-fruit notes on the palate and sells for a reasonable price: Millard Fillmore United States Brandy, $35, Caddell & Williams, 800-575-9997, caddellwilliams.com.

title: Leader of Malaysia, Miffed at U.S., Visits China With a Deal in Mind
description: BEIJING  Malaysias prime minister, miffed by a Justice Department investigation into his nations sovereign wealth fund, arrived in Beijing on Monday ready to buy Chinese military hardware, a deal that will rattle his relationship with the United States.

title: Make Room for a Cheese Cave in Your Fridge
description: Storing fine cheeses properly at home has long been a challenge. You can invest in special double-ply wrapping paper, but the temperature and humidity of a refrigerator do not flatter them. Working with an engineer and an industrial designer, Jessica Sennett, who has been behind the counters at Cowgirl Creamery and Bedford Cheese Shop, has developed a solution. Her Cheese Grotto is a sturdy box with removable wooden shelves, a clay slab in the bottom and ventilation ducts in the back. Moisture is maintained by periodically soaking the clay. Cheeses are stored unwrapped. The boxs footprint is around the size of a standard sheet of copy paper, and at 8 inches high, it can fit in a refrigerator or sit comfortably on a kitchen counter. It can be ordered for $350 and will ship four weeks after the order date: cheesegrotto.com.

title: Daily Report: Googles Day in Europes Court Highlights Nature of New Tech
description: Europe has a big headache: the current state of American technology companies. And it may take a long time to go away.

title: Escape the Web and Get Things Done
description: Q. Im going to take up the NaNoWriMo challenge, but am worried about giving in to internet distractions and not finishing the novel by the end of November. I only need discipline for a month, so what free or cheap software would work to temporarily lock me out of the Facebook and other time-sapping sites?

title: Strangers on a Strange Election
description: The 2016 U.S. presidential campaign as experienced by four writers originally from somewhere else.

title: Delmonicos Welcomes a White House Chef
description: Over the decades, Delmonicos Restaurant has counted heads of state among its customers, including more than a dozen American presidents. Now the restaurant has turned to John Moeller, a former White House chef (from 1992 to 2005), to work with its executive chef, Billy Oliva, on a menu of dishes that have been served to commanders in chief at Delmonicos and at the White House. The menu, including roast duck and sweet potato bisque, crab  la Newburg, turkey  la king, goulash and baked alaska, will be available from Tuesday to Nov. 8 for lunch and dinner: Presidential Palates menu, Delmonicos Restaurant, 56 Beaver Street (South William Street), 212-509-1144, delmonicosrestaurant.com.

title: Gabriel Kreuthers Chocolate Shop Opens
description: The chocolate shop adjacent to Gabriel Kreuthers restaurant has some compelling features. Chefs in a glass-encased space enrobe chocolates as visitors watch them work. The two display cases in the soaring shop tempt with chocolates and pastries, among them macarons with a series of fillings based on cheesecakes, a sort of France-meets-America concept, as the pastry chef, Marc Aumont, put it. Among the flavors, there is the inevitable pumpkin spice. A few cafe tables are set out in the metallic-flecked room for customers to enjoy coffee and sweets but not much else: Kreuther Handcrafted Chocolate, 43 West 42nd Street, 212-201-1985.

title: Anson Mills Grains Now Available in New York
description: For cornmeal, farro, oats or other grains from Anson Mills, the Columbia, S.C., company renowned for its high-quality heirloom products, you used to place your order on the website. But now, a few of the items, including popping corn and cornmeal for polenta, are being sold at the retail counter at Il Buco Alimentari e Vineria, in the East Village. The new baker on the premises, Sheena Otto (below), who was at Bien Cuit, is introducing some breads using Anson Mills grains, including a crusty dark rye and a buckwheat rye. Ms. Otto, who believes in a slow fermentation with no added yeast, is also baking a complex seed-studded multigrain in two sizes, and fragrant bourbon and raisin bread: Anson Mills products, $5.50 to $8; new breads, $6 to $12. Il Buco Alimentari e Vineria, 53 Great Jones Street (Bowery), 212-837-2622, ilbucovineria.com.

title: Bright, Geometric Earrings to Fall for
description: Consider the seasons striking dangling designs.

title: Want to Quit Office Life to Work With Your Hands? Ask These Guys
description: Ben Schickel walked into the offices of a software firm in Boston, where he had worked in sales for more than a year. It wasnt easy. He was coming back from a two-week vacation, time he had spent not on some faraway beach but indulging his passion for landscaping work.

title: The Store Putting Tijuana on the Design Map
description: Within Mexico, Tijuanas mestizo culture is renowned: The citys booming manufacturing industry attracts migrant workers from all over the country, who bring with them disparate cultural traditions whose influence has long been felt in the music and food scenes. Now, it is on display at Object, a pioneering design shop in the city. Most of the designers we carry work directly with traditional Mexican artisans from all over Mexico, says its owner, Vernica Hernndez. She and the stores other co-owners travel throughout the country to source designs that often reflect regional manufacturing methods.

title: Study Finds Some Uber and Lyft Drivers Racially Discriminate
description: By tapping into new technologies and the ubiquitous use of smartphones, the likes of Uber and Lyft  rival ride-booking services  were supposed to solve many of the problems that litter the traditional economy.

title: Chinas Gift to President Duterte
description: Is the anti-American vitriol of President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines beginning to pay off?

title: Touring Maines Newest  and Largest  Parcel of Federal Land
description: On an early fall day, with just a hint of red tinting the maples, the view from the summit of Deasey Mountain is spectacular.

description: To the Editor:

title: Police Killing of Mentally Ill Black Man Is, 5 Years Later, Headed to Trial
description: WHITE PLAINS  Kenneth Chamberlain Sr. had accidentally triggered his medical alert pendant early one morning five years ago. A former Marine and corrections officer, he had bipolar disorder, as well as arthritis and respiratory illness.

title: CNN Parts Ways With Donna Brazile, a Hillary Clinton Supporter

description: If youre seeing a wave of Facebook friends suddenly checking in to the Standing Rock Indian Reservation in Cannon Ball, N.D., online, its probably not because theyve decided to travel to the site of tense protests  between the police and activists against the Dakota Access oil pipeline.

description: After a 52-year championship sports drought, Cleveland has emphatically ended the spell.

title: Newfound Millipede Is Toothy, Poisonous and Quite Male
description: It has 414 legs, a pear-shaped head covered with stiff hairs that secrete a silklike substance, a lip with a tooth-lined slit, and two nozzles on each of its 100 segments that give off a defensive poison.

title: Royal Court Theater Announces World Premiere Lineup
description: LONDON  A stage adaptation of The Kid Stays in the Picture, about the tumultuous career of the movie producer Robert Evans, and Nuclear War, by the Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time playwright Simon Stephens are among the plays that will have their world premieres at the Royal Court Theater in 2017, the company announced Monday.

description: Last week, the Food section published an article detailing, in hard numbers, how daunting the financial climate is for restaurateurs in New York. But Keith McNally, who has opened more restaurants than most, and kept most of them open, believes that money is only part of the equation.

title: Pakistani Police Clash With Backers of Opposition Leader Imran Khan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Clashes erupted Monday between the riot police and thousands of supporters of the opposition politician Imran Khan in northwestern Pakistan, ahead of his plan to hold a protest in the Pakistani capital later this week.

title: Peter Thiels Fantasy Trump
description: In the world according to Peter Thiel, the technology entrepreneur and billionaire, liberals and journalists are easily distracted children. Preoccupied with the words that come out of Donald Trumps mouth, they are not taking seriously the Republican candidates diagnosis of what is hurting the country: wars, trade and government regulations.

title: Why Blame Huma Abedin?
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Has Few Ways to Fight Misconduct During Investigation
description: The disclosure of an investigation can have a devastating effect, as Hillary Clinton learned on Friday. But the targets of federal inquiries have few tools available to fight back. The governments power to investigate is almost unlimited, with no real avenue imposed by courts to provide any redress for an individual harmed by the publicity surrounding a case.

title: That Historic Cocktail? Turns Out Its a Fake

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Talibans internal debate over whether and how to negotiate with the Afghan government is playing out in the open, even as there have been renewed attempts to restart talks.

title: Judge Rejects Settlement Over Surveillance of Muslims by New York Police Department

title: Why Clintons Emails Matter
description: It may come as a surprise that one of this countrys greatest experts on Richard M. Nixons many crimes is, in fact, Hillary Clinton. In 1974 she was, by many accounts, among the brightest members of the staff of the House Judiciary Committee that investigated Nixon and prepared the articles of impeachment. In this bizarre election year, it must be painful to her that she should find herself at the center of a scandal described by her hyperbolic political opponent, Donald J. Trump, as worse than Watergate.

title: Review: A Musical Homage to Aviation, From Plato to Earhart
description: The armchairs in the Board of Officers Room at the Park Avenue Armory are surely the most comfortable concert-hall seats in New York. And yet I couldnt stop squirming during Sunday afternoons performance there of Flight, a multimedia concoction for string quartet, electronics and video conceived by the composer Roger Reynolds. Billed as a tribute to humanitys fascination with flying, the work draws on images and texts spanning some 3,000 years, and thats about how long it felt, thanks to the flat-footed and dispiriting way in which it was all cobbled together.

title: Mark Carney to Lead Bank of England Through June 2019
description: LONDON  Mark Carney, the Bank of England governor, said on Monday that he would serve an additional year as head of the central bank and step down in June 2019.

title: Canary Islands Are Alternate Site for Planned Mauna Kea Telescope
description: An international consortium of astronomers whose plan to erect a giant telescope on Mauna Kea in Hawaii has been stalled by protests and legal challenges said on Monday that it would build the telescope in the Canary Islands if it was blocked in Hawaii.

description: LUND, Sweden  Almost 500 years after Martin Luther nailed his 95 theses to a church door, setting off more than a century of religious warfare and forever changing the practice of Christianity worldwide, Pope Francis on Monday urged atonement and Christian reconciliation.

title: Medical Charities Once Advised on Coping With a Disease. Now They Try to Cure It.

On Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall, the foundation delivered. Among the roster of artists were Anna Netrebko, Rene Fleming, Joyce DiDonato, Javier Camarena, Lawrence Brownlee, Kristine Opolais, Nadine Sierra and Jamie Barton.

description: The most prominent sculptures at Tufts University, my alma mater just outside Boston, show Jumbo, the storied circus elephant permanently lodged in the colleges mythology. But a fascinating artistic discovery is shedding new light on a lesser known, but perhaps more consequential, piece of the colleges history.

title: In Atlanta, a Soundtrack That Subtly Whispers Its Locale
description: For a show ostensibly about a fledgling rap career, the experimental FX comedy Atlanta has a light, naturalistic touch with music. There are no predictably triumphant performance scenes or recording studio breakthroughs, no overwrought montages set to obvious pop songs.

title: Vine Dries Up. Black Humor Loses a Home
description: This summer, I thumbed past an Instagram photo of a familiar-looking young man with silken brown skin and an enviable high-top fade dressed up in an azure suit. I lingered for a moment, slightly verklempt. I knew him, or, at least, I felt as if I did, and I couldnt believe he was already going to prom.

description: Childrens use of smartphones and tablets near bedtime is linked to poor sleep and daytime drowsiness, a new analysis has found.

description: The biggest super PAC in the presidential race is opening up a last-minute burst of advertising on Hillary Clintons behalf, seeking to bolster her in three hotly contested states as she fends off renewed questions about her private email server.

title: Colombia Is Hit Hard by Zika, but Not by Microcephaly
description: BARRANQUILLA, Colombia  This tropical city on the Caribbean coast may hold the answer to one of the deeper mysteries of the Zika epidemic: Why has the worlds second-largest outbreak, after Brazils, produced so few birth defects?

title: Come From Away in Newfoundland
description: A town that gave succor on Sept. 11, 2001, gets a pre-Broadway taste of the new musical.

title: A 9/11 Parable, Resurrected in Newfoundland
description: GANDER, Newfoundland  Memories of Sept. 11 are a little different here. That was the morning 38 planes were diverted to this tight-knit town with a large airfield, where they were required to land because of fear about how many flights might be targeted in the terrorist attacks unfolding south of the border. The day 6,700 bewildered passengers arrived, upset and tired, unsure why they were here or how long it would take them to get out.
